direction.raw_text: . A SUMMER'S DAY, 1912. The bucolic magnificence of the Devon countryside. We fly low over the high, thick hedges untouched for hundreds of years. The thick verdant countryside in all its splendor, ancient woodlands, fields of corn, and finally a paddock in a typical Devonshire dale. We come to rest beside three farmers standing over a pregnant mare. The mare is in distress - she is about to give birth. The farmers calm the mare and tend to her gently with assurance and authority. We pull back to see, ALBERT, a fifteen-year-old farm boy, watching the whole drama with delight from the paddock gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, easy, girl. Easy, girl. Easy. The men hold the mare firmly, but clearly this is a difficult birth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a stubborn one, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There we go. Who's a clever girl? Moments later - the summer's sun glints off the wet, sticky hide of the foal (JOEY) - red hide, four white socks and a distinctive white cross on its forehead. Soon the creature is attempting its first clumsy steps. It is both awesome and comical to see the new born creature struggle to his feet, but eventually, he succeeds. Title: WAR HORSE EXT. PADDOCK/FIELD, DEVON. VARIOUS. We follow Joey's progress over the course of his first year. His initial fearfulness, his connection with his mother, the intimacy of their relationship. As Joey gets strong they run together, frolicking gayly in the last dregs of summer. Albert looking on. Joey notices him at the fence and they share a moment of connection. Spring: flowers are beginning to sprout by the hedgerows. Our boy Albert runs into the field. He takes an apple from his pocket - he holds it out tentatively. Joey approaches Albert with suspicion. Albert gently encourages him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . His mother paws the ground and neighs at Joey. He turns and runs over the field at her beck and call. Albert tosses the apple to himself, ruefully - watches in awe as Joey races away with his mother. He is a magnificent one year old. His distinctive red coat gleaming, now it is clear that he is half thoroughbred. He runs quickly around the field enjoying his own power and strength. Later - the three farmers open the gate and come into the field. Both Joey and his mother instinctively canter over to the two men, expecting food. The three men gently greet the horses and pet them, then we see one man has a noose made of a rope. He slips it round Mum's neck. She pulls back, Joey is shaken and bewildered but before he knows what's happening the second farmer is trying to get a similar rope around his neck. Joey balks and pushes the farmer aside, distressed to see his mother tethered. The farmer grabs Joey again and struggles with him, enlisting the help of the second farmer. With some effort they get the rope around his neck and calm him down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Easy does it. Easy does it. Come on, steady does it. Unused to being tethered Joey pulls at the rope but the farmers are solid and firm. They gently lead Joey and his mother across the field to the gate and out into the road. The whole road becomes overtaken by a flock of sheep on their way to the market. In the distance we hear the bustle of Market Day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. The farmers lead Joey and his mother through the chaos of the market and into an auction pen. They find themselves amongst a hoard of pigs, sheep and cows. Joey is agog at all of these creatures and all this life he had no idea existed. The farmers lead the horses into a stall to await the auction. Joey is bewildered by all the noise - buttressed against a couple of mules and a cow. He is uncomfortable in this tight space. An AUCTION WORKER holds a clipboard out for the lead farmer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mornin', pop. Put your mark here. Good luck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Two men approach the pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get the colt... One man grabs Joey and pulls him out of the pen. Suddenly there is a look of horror on his face. His terrified mother realises they are being separated. Joey panics and desperately tries to get back to his mother, he rises up throwing the man who is leading him aside. Joey is out of control. The man regains control of Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa! Whoa! He pulls Joey away from his mother, who lets out a heart- rending cry, paws the ground, and crashes her foreleg against the fence. Joey remains disoriented in the midst of the market day chaos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Easy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. The auction ring is full of people of all shapes and sizes. There is a sense of celebration and busyness about market day. We concentrate on two men - Ted Narracott (DAD), in his forties, clearly both the cares of the world and alcohol have worn him down before his time, and SI EASTON, his more solid friend, both working farmers. Just behind Si is his 15 year old son, ANDREW. Ted has a drink in his hand. They all look at Joey bridling against the men who are trying to hold him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that's a beauty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget it, Ted. He's half thoroughbred and not got a day's work in him. (points to a plow horse next to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, there... There's your ticket. In contrast to Joey, the solid and bulky plow horse stands like a rock. But Dad remains fixated on Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But look at him, Si. Look at that creature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Indeed, Joey is magnificent, his power clearly emerging because of his upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be daft. You need something solid to plow a field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (fixed on Joey) Yeah, but he's something else, that one. The AUCTIONEER announces the start of the auction...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright gentlemen - settle down - settle down - horses on my right - men with money in their pockets on my left - it's the perfect combination. Is Fred Goddard here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shouts his reply from the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! I's here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good - more money than sense. Dave Hill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here. Yes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bugger off, you tight bastard - you've been coming here for 20 years - never bought so much as a pork scratching. The crowd are loving all this. Dad notices a figure across the ring, LYONS, clearly a man of money. You can see something light up in Dad's eyes - a combination of dislike and alcohol. Joey is led into the auction pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay - first up today - a gorgeous young horse - prettiest thing I've seen since my wife on our wedding day. Let's get going, shall we? Who wants this wonderful creature. But no-one bids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One guinea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One guinea, one guinea, one guinea...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you needed a plow horse, Mister Narracott.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any advance on one guinea? Any advance on one guinea? Joey is still trying to get back to his mother. A voice from the crowd pipes up:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two guineas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted Narracott - it's completely the wrong animal. Lyons whispers to his son, DAVID, 15, next to him. David eyes Joey skeptically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Si Easton - I'm not gonna let that bastard see me off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five guineas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh for the love of...! Joey is straining to get to his mother, the men are pulling him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greedy sod thinks he can just buy anybody. (BIDDING) Eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop it - he's your landlord - you can't be picking fights with him. Lyons looks over. There is now tension in the crowd as they sense a Battle Royal for the horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten guineas. He smirks at Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You haven't got the money. Let's go home - let's have a pint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleven guineas, sir, from as good a man as any in this town. They all look at Lyons in his suit and bowler hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I hear twelve guineas? Twelve guineas?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's top price for a workin' animal. Ted! Save it for the shire!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are big days and there are small days. Which will it be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I hear any advance on eleven guineas? All eyes are on Lyons and his son - David is 15, smartly dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just let him go, dad, I don't care for him, he's too... jumpy. Lyons isn't listening to David; he's looking hard at Ted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we say - twenty five? The crowd gasps. This is clearly personal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he's got you there. Nice try, Ted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were great, Mr N. Gave him a run for his money. But when he looks at Ted, Ted's eyes are locked into the eyes of his rival.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Going, going...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirty. Thirty guineas! Total silence. He stares hard at Lyons. Who simply smiles, raises an eyebrow, tips his hat and walks away. It dawns on Dad that he's won the auction. He breaks into a sweat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirty guineas. Thirty guineas. Going going gone - to Mister Ted Narracott. He bangs his gavel. It's a done deal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you done, Ted? What have you done? Dad doesn't acknowledge Si. Moments later - Ted stands staring at Joey, who looks back. Ted holds his reins numbly, accepts his receipt from the auction man in a kind of daze. Suddenly, Lyons appears at Dad's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite a beast, there. But what you gonna do with him - on a working farm? I hope you got the rent, Ted. I'll be around for it when it comes due. Dad does not acknowledge Lyons. Lyons smiles and walks away with son David, and his cronies. Si shakes his head at Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a fool, Ted. And our Rosie'll never forgive you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUNSET.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT kneels in her garden, digging up some carrots, when she sees Ted returning. Dad walks down the hedged lane as the sun sets pulling Joey with him, his bad leg always moving slightly to the side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mrs. Narracott looks in horror and bewilderment at Joey and then at Dad. She is a good-looking, intelligent woman, but clearly her life is always hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT What have you done? Dad stands shamefaced as Albert - the boy we have already met - runs out of the house to join them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's Mooney's colt!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT You were supposed to buy a plow horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bought him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT What'd you pay for him? Albert is totally taken by the horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT (CONT'D) How much, Ted Narracott?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't tell you a lie - though I would love to. Thirty guineas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Thirty guineas! She is stunned. She looks at Ted - and he just nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT (CONT'D) He's not worth ten! Are you out of your mind? What about the rent?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a strong one, Rosie. Look at the way he holds his head!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT How the hell are we gonna pull anything with that? Ted - you have to take him back. You have to take him back right now now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT You have to get down on your knees and beg for our money back. Joey bridles at the raised voices but Albert takes the rope and tries to calm him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No, please don't take him back. Suddenly we see Dad's dejection. He is a man lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't take him back till he's broken in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT And how are you gonna train a horse with that leg?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll train him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT No, you stay out of this, Albie. You don't know nothing about horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Mum. Please let me. I can do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to keep him. We've no choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Right. Well... you've got one month to break him in or I'm taking him back myself. (She turns to the house, but then...) How did you get to thirty - what other fool bid you up that high?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was Lyons. Mrs. Narracott turns back towards the house, then stops, dazed, speaking almost to herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT We're gonna lose everything. After all we've been through - we're gonna lose it all. She turns back to the others - the weight of the mistake heavy on their shoulders - but Albert quickly steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, Mum - I'll raise him - and I'll raise him good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Well, you better. Go on - get started. See if a child can undo what your fool of a father's done to this family of ours. Mrs. Narracott storms into the house. Albert immediately goes to stroke Joey but the nervous horse draws back uncomfortably. Dad leads him off, drunk and bewildered, across the yard to the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER. Albert loads some oats into a bucket and approaches Joey in the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. Let's make a start then. As Albert approaches, Joey nervously runs in circles, then stops on a dime, looking at Albert suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's oats. Very tasty, that is. It's beef and gravy to us! Albert squats down. He shows the food. Joey catches the scent on the air, but still hesitates and shies away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on... This time, Albert takes a new tact, almost turning his body fully away from Joey, but keeping the bucket extended. Albert slowly backs towards Joey, speaking gently all the while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bet you're missing your mother. Look at you... first time without your mum. First time away from home. But you're not alone, are you. In fact. Cos I'm `ere... Feeling safer, Joey moves toward the bucket of oats and starts to eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's alright. It's alright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Albert reaches out his hand and touches Joey. And with a slight start, the horse relaxes into Albert's hand, feeling safe with the boy. Albert stares at the distinctive white cross on Joey's forehead. Joey calms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna call you Joey. Understand? Joey. That's you. And I'm Albert. It's alright, You're mine now. You're mine. Albert strokes Joey's forehead. Joey lifts his head and the two stare at each other in close proximity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEXT DAY. Dad, with a hangover, hobbles off to work the fields. As he reaches the gate, HAROLD the goose snaps at his heels. Dad dismisses him with a stare and heads for the stables.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE FARMYARD, DAY. The training episode: Albert walks Joey around the yard on the rope. It all seems to be going well. Mum looks on. Albert is clearly proud of his progress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANOTHER DAY. Albert's friend, Andrew Easton, sits on a rock with an apple in hand to watch the training. Albert sets Joey in a spot and tells him to wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa. I want you to stay there, Joey. Stay. That's it. Good boy. That's it, you've got it. Of course when Albert walks away, Joey follows. A game of "Grandma's footsteps" ensues as Albert patiently places Joey then walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, look at him, Albie. He's playing "Grandma's Footsteps." Albert patiently leads Joey back to his starting position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, come on, Joey. Back you go. Come on. Back you go. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're all right. That's it. Good boy. Right. You've gotta stay there, understand? Albert walks away again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it. Good boy. You've got it. Good boy. Finally Joey stays put. Andrew smiles, impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good boy. Good. (TO ALBERT) Now call him. Whistle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come now, Joey. Come on. Albert whistles like an owl. Joey stands completely still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can come now, Joey. He whistles again. Joey remains still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't think he fancies your owls. Albert walks back to Joey, frustrated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I read it in a story. It's how the Indians used to summon their horses. He gently strokes Joey's nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, Joey, when I whistle, you've gotta come, understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dad had a dog who stayed when you called him. He used to run up behind you when you weren't looking, and uh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not a dog. He's just puzzling it through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Albert runs further away than before and whistles. After a moment, Joey trots over to him. Andrew smiles broadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brilliant. Look at you. With the basis established, Albert begins to train Joey to react to the owl whistle without his prompting. It's not all easy going - sometimes Albert makes progress, sometimes not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Mrs. Narracott fills a bucket at the pump, then promptly spills it when Joey trots past her in response to an owl whistle. She calls off, frustrated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Albie. Dad heads out to the fields with a rake on his shoulder. There's an owl call and Joey trots past him in the background. Dad sees Albert welcome Joey by the haystacks, stroking his nose affectionately. Dad walks on, his expression inscrutable. Joey trots up a path, pursuing another owl call. After several more calls, he still can't spot Albert, until he cranes his neck up and sees Albert sitting in a nearby tree. Albert laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER. Lyons is there with his son, David, and his unlikable cronies. He holds a meager handful of cash. Dad and Mum look chastened. The mood is sombre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's only fifteen here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rest will come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know by rights I could take this farm back today, don't you? And I'm a great believer in my rights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you drank less beer and bought fewer horses you might be able to look your landlord in the eye, Narracott. Lyons begins loading up his ledger into his bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said I'll pay you. We got to plant the bottom field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bottom field's rock hard. Only stones down there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, we're going to plow it. Just give me `til the autumn. I'll pay every penny I owe you. With interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How you going to plow it? Not with that fancy animal of yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll not get that one in a harness, let alone pulling a plow. Even drunk on a Tuesday night, you know that. And I can't wait for the money - there's a war coming. Dad stands up from his chair, resolute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promise you that field will be plowed. We'll plant it with turnips. And the money will be yours when harvest comes. Mrs. Narracott interjects, desperate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Please, sir. Please. Lyons takes his time. He looks at them both - Ted and Rosie, almost beaten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well - if that fancy plows that field I'll give you till October to set things straight. Lyons heads for the door, but Albert stands in his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if he doesn't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take the horse on the day he fails. (BEAT) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'll take your father's farm and give it to working men who can hold their pints and hold their heads high in decent company. Lyons tries to move past, but Albert grabs his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, please. Sir, you can't do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, now, now, lad. What - are you bladdered as well?! Ted Narracott - I got you down in my book! Albert knows he has to back down. Lyons walks past him and leaves with David and his cronies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Harold the goose attacks Lyons and his men. They quickly pile into his car and drive off. Ted stands in the kitchen immobile with upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOMENTS LATER. Dad throws open the stable door, jerks the harness from the wall, throws open Joey's stall and starts to lunge at the horse. Albert runs in to try to stop him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't harness him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got to be collared. Dad starts to grapple with Joey desperately flailing in an attempt to get the harness onto Joey. Joey is completely confused and frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you can't. Look, you're scaring him, Dad. You're scaring him. He... (DESPERATE) He can't take a plow! Joey tries to push Dad out of the way, Dad frustrated by this hits Joey hard with the harness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got to plow!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't be able to do it - he's too young - he's not even been backed yet.... Joey rears up and kicks Dad. Who falls to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Ted! Albert grabs Joey's bridle. Joey wrestles with Albert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's alright, boy. It's alright. It's alright. It's alright. Dad is mad with anger and frustration - and in pain. He staggers to his feet and leaves. Albert calms Joey down. Mrs. Narracott returns the harness to its hook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT I knew this would happen soon as I laid eyes on him.... But then she notices Dad has returned. He has a gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT (CONT'D) Ted. No. Ted, no!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's worth nothing to me! If he won't take the collar, he's not worth a damn thing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad? He grabs the rifle, but Dad shoves him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Move aside. Dad raises the rifle, but Albert wrestles for it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad. Stop. Furious with frustration Dad throws Albert to the ground and takes aim at the horse. Mrs. Narracott quickly pulls the gun aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT You shoot that horse we have nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Dad whips the gun back towards Joey to find Albert standing between them - right in front of the gun's barrel. For a second we think Albert will be inadvertently shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT (CONT'D) NO! Dad pauses his finger just in time. Albert gently holds the barrel of the gun. Speaks calmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were right what you said, Dad. "He'll do it," you told Lyons, "He'll plow that field." And he will! You'll see. He'll show you. We'll show you. We'll get it done. Dad looks at him, frozen. Mrs. Narracott eases the gun away from him -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let go. Let go. - and hands it to Albert, telling him -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go back to the house. As Albert leaves, Ted takes out his flask. But Rosie takes it from him gently. He doesn't resist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Here, here. Some days are best forgotten. Today ain't one of them. Come on. They exit the stable together, leaving Joey in his stall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STABLES. DAWN. Albert walks towards the stables - enters. And talks to Joey as he prepares the harness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you today, Joey? I don't know much about life, boy, but I do know that there are big days and there are small days. And most days are small days, and, well, they don't matter much to anyone - but this - well, this is a big one. This is our big day. Well, it's cold out there. So I'm going to take this off - (he takes off his coat) Well, if it's tough for you - it should be tough for me, too...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He is left in just a loose-fitting white shirt....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, I'm gonna teach you how to plow and you're gonna learn. Is that understood? And then we can be together, which is how I believe things are meant to be. Joey instinctively balks, but Albert is stern with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy. Steady, boy. Here we go. Here we go. As he approaches Joey with the harness, Harold the goose enters the stable to watch. Albert approaches gently and slowly puts the harness over his own neck and shoulders to demonstrate -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Easy, easy... Look at me, Joey. See? See? You've just gotta put your nose through. It is a moment between them. The horse looks Albert in the eye, then yields. Albert comforts him and show there is nothing to fear. Finally he gets the harness in place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it. See? You've got it. You've got it. Good boy. There... Harold honks his approval. Albert leads Joey out across the yard, through the broken gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. It is a grey day as they walk across the plowed fields towards the huge lower field. They come to a rusty, primitive plow left in the grass. Albert looks around the field - it is overgrown, it seems to go on forever - even if Joey was a plow horse this would be a heavy task. Si Easton and Andrew stroll up the road to watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too large, too rocky, matted with grass roots. Even a sturdy plow horse'd never manage it alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yet he will, I say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd swear he'd sprout wings and fly if Albert had told you so. (smiling at his son:) It's a fine thing, loyal to your mate. Even if he is a bit barmy. A team of two might manage, given a month and good weather. They're interrupted by the honk of a horn as Lyons and David pull up in a car. Lyons and David get out. Their driver remains inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted too squeamish to watch, is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `Course he's watching. Si nods in the direction of the house. Albert steadies Joey and starts to tie on the heavy plow. It just seems too big and bulky for Joey's sleek frame. Albert sets Joey right and fixes the plow. Lyons, David, Si, and Andrew walk towards Dad, who looks on anxiously from a nearby hedgerow. Lyons gestures at David to stay back and walks over to Ted alone. He stands beside him and begins to talk gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you've raised him up a true Narracott, Ted, picture of his father, he is: not a dollop of ordinary sense but that thick stubbornness that'll lead him to insist on the impossible. Down in the field, Albert continues to prep the plow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wasn't a farmer in Devon didn't admire you, myself among `em, leaving your brothers that fine farm and setting yourself at this stoney patch of unpromising ground. You've fettle enough for twenty men, but with a gimpy leg and the drinking - for the pain, isn't it, that you drink? (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - yeah, none of us could have anticipated an ending better than this. Makes me question the wisdom of the charity that urged me to rent you this place, not only looking at you, me old pal, but that pretty little wife of yours, thought you were a spark, she did. Ted hasn't acknowledged Lyons for a second; he's never taken his eyes off Albert. He simply stands and walks away as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now your son's sinking into the selfsame bog that's swallowing you. Albert has been meticulously preparing everything, positioning Joey, checking the tethers, digging the rusty plow in the earth. He takes his position behind the plow, throwing the rear leather harness over his own neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See Joey - I got the collar, too! Albert gently snaps the reins. Joey doesn't move, confused by the whole affair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, boy. Walk on. That's it. Walk on! Walk on, Joey. Come on, boy, walk on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd be better off startin' at the top of the hill and goin' down! Gravity's the only friend you're gonna have today, young lad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walk on, Joey! Walk on! Come on, Joey, walk on. Walk on, boy. At the house, Mrs. Narracott opens an upstairs window to look on, anxiously. Ted, standing alone by the fence, only looks at Albert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walk on. Come on, walk on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll take the whip to move him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Just as Ted is saying this, Albert, as if hearing his father, takes a breath and then abruptly produces a whip. Joey's ears prick up. Albert, grimly determined, snaps the whip at Joey. Joey panics and bolts. The plow spins to its side, pulls Albert off his feet. Joey drags them all the way to the top of the hill, right by the farmhouse. Lyons, yelling, starts laughing and can't stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bravo! You've reached the top of the hill! Off you go again, boy! You'll make even better time comin' down!! He continues past Dad, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Mrs. Narracott looks on from the house. He glances back at her. Her face is full of angry concern for their son. Townsfolk begin arriving, climbing the hill to the lower field. Ted looks down, ashamed. Mrs. Narracott looks back at Albert, mortified, bruised, setting the plow right again. Mrs. Narracott moves away from the window, takes a seat, and picks up her knitting. Later - Albert has made no progress. Joey is moving, but only in a useless circle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good boy. Good lad. Good lad. Now walk on. Good boy. More townsfolk clamor to the fence. Andrew calls out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albie, we're all with ya! Albert tries to encourage him forward but Joey still isn't pulling sufficiently. The plow skips uselessly over the surface stones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look look look! The plow hasn't even cut yet! As Albert struggles with the plow, he sees Dad walking up the hill behind the spectators. He doesn't even turn to his son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Joey strains as Albert pushes with all his might. We sense the strain on the horse and the inappropriateness of the task. But Joey perseveres. The plow limps along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know - I believe we can do it, Joey. I knew when I first saw you that you'd be the best of us. That's why he bought you. He knows you've all the courage he never had. I knew when I first saw you that you'd be the one who'd save us. The plow skips and Albert falls. Joey's legs buckle and he goes to his knees. Albert rushes to his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa. Whoa. Lyons calls from the crowd as rain starts to fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got no chance, lad. He'll not turn over half an acre. Give it up now. You've done well. You've tried hard. You're more of a man than your father. Albert examines the collar - he sees it is ripping into Joey's flesh. He grabs his shirt, tears a piece off it, tenderly folds it and puts it between Joey's shoulder and the collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on now, Mr. Lyons, that's a bit rough, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he'll destroy that horse. The crowd's beginning to disperse. One of Lyons' cronies holds his umbrella as he returns to his car. He passes Ted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be over Thursday. Give you a day to close it up. Mrs. Narracott emerges from the house and heads to the fence - holding her knitting in the rain, ignoring the leaving crowds. A SYMPATHETIC NEIGHBOR hands her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your wool. (THEN) I'm sorry, Rosie. Lyons passes behind her, almost speaks, but then thinks better of it. As the rain intensifies, Albert digs his toe into the wet soil and notices how it has softened. Suddenly something flashes through Albert's mind. He leaps into action, runs through the rain to shout at Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, boy! You've got to do it, Joey. You don't know, so I'm gonna have to do the knowing for you when the rest of our lives depend on this! So get set to pull - and pull straight! And pull hard! He races back to the plow and sets himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, boy! Go! Joey pulls firmly and finally the inertia is broken - the rain has softened the earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walk on, Joey! Walk on! That's it! Good boy, Joey! Good boy! Finally, the plow bites deep into the soil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walk on! Walk on! Walk on! Walk on, Joey! At the fence, Mrs. Narracott looks on in amazement. Albert notices a large rock in their path. Andrew sees it, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go around it!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa, Joey! Whoa, Joey! Joey! Joey, whoa whoa whoa! Joey, stop! You'll break the blade - 24. Albert hauls back on the reins, but Joey throws his flanks forward, straining and lurching until the plow blade splits the rock completely in half and now the plow moves more easily through the wet ground. The ground yields. Soon Albert and Joey are making great progress. The wet earth slipping open beneath them. Andrew is loving it, speaks in wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you look at you? Mrs. Narracott looks very happy, a smile breaking slowly across her face... The crowd begins to return. Lyons notices and looks out from his car - sees the plow digging through the field. Annoyed at the progress Albert's making, he gets out of his car and walks over to Mrs. Narracott. With great disdain he
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd not let a child of mine slip in the mud alongside a plow blade. He could lose a foot! Mrs. Narracott brandishes her knitting needles, backing him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll likelier lose an eye, Mr. Lyons, if you carry on prating at me how to manage my son! Or my plow, or my horse, or my field, or my farm! Dad sits nearby, watching this exchange with silent approval. Lyons stares at her, gape-mouthed, as she turns her attention back to Albert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Come on, Albie! Push on through! The rain becomes torrential. Lyons turns towards the car - gestures, frustrated, to his driver, who runs forward with the umbrella to shield his boss from the rain. David remains on the running board, watching Albert plowing. The plow speeds through the earth. The boy and the horse are working as one. It is a moment of triumph.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get it done, Albie! Get it done!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . We pull back to see they have made only the smallest dent in the enormous field. As Lyons' car passes, Dad steps forward, takes in the scene, and almost smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. The rain has abated. Albert, soaked to the skin, sits next to Joey. They are both covered in mud. Andrew, followed by Si Easton, charges through the gate up to Albert. They are lifting Albert up between them, laughing, Si Easton planting a kiss on Albert's muddy cheek, Andrew tousling his filthy hair, when Mrs. Narracott arrives with Ted. She helps Si and Andrew lift Albert and slings her son's arm over her shoulder, glowing with pride, crying, overjoyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my pair of fools. My mighty fools. As the others help Albert up, Ted tends to Joey. He looks over to his son and, after a moment, removes his cap and slightly bows his head. The others stagger away, supporting Albert, and Ted pats the horse and gently begins to unbuckle the harness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Albert washes Joey and tends the wounds and sores on his body. Rosie is putting antiseptic on Albert's wrists and shoulders. Joey bristles but is soothed by Albert's care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're as battered and bloodied as he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And where's Dad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still in the bottom field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stumbling about, I suppose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not the drink, Albert, that makes him stumble - 26.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drinks, mum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, so might you if you'd been where he's been, seen what he's seen!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he don't talk to me about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He don't talk about it because he can't. There aren't words for some things. Come here... Rosie stalks over to a pile of broken equipment in a corner of the stables. She rummages until she finds a waterstained brown paper parcel tied with yarn. She brushes away some mouse turds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mice've been at it. Sit down. They sit together on a step. As she begins to untie the yarn, a change comes over her: her irritated determination gives way to sadness. Albert comes to her and kneels beside her as she gently opens the paper. Inside there's a red and tan pennant, knotted and fringed at both ends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Here. It's his campaign pennant. He were Sergeant, Seventh Battalion, Imperial Yeomanry. Then with great care she unfolds the sash to reveal two silver medals. The first, with the profile of Victoria, hangs from a red, blue and orange ribbon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that is the Queen's South Africa Medal. Every man who fought in the Boer War got one of those. But this... She holds up the other medal, hanging from a red and black ribbon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the Distinguished Conduct Medal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She hands Albert the Distinguished Conduct Medal. He takes it, astonished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not dad's?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well it ain't mine, dear. He got that after the fighting at Transvaal. After he'd been hurt, and he'd saved some other lads, and well... I don't know what else, he won't tell me either. But the first day he got home he just... tossed them out. First day he could walk, he threw `em straight in the dustbin, and wouldn't hear a word I said not to. Albert nods, looking at the medal and campaign pennant. She takes the medal back, puts it in the sash, and begins to wrap it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, what you done today, you and Joey, you're chuffed up now, and so you should be, my splendid boy. It's good to be proud when you done something good. But what he done, in Africa, whatever it was, he takes no pride in it. Hard as it surely was, and however much pain it's cost him, he refuses to be proud of killing, I suppose. She returns the things in the footlocker, closes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd be proud. If I'd gone off to war. If I'd gone and saved my mates, and -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, whether or not you think you'd do the same thing as him... Think how brave he is for refusing to be proud. She heads back to Albert, pennant in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, your dad makes mistakes. And he drinks to forget the mistakes that he's made - but he never gave up and he does that for us. And today, you showed the world it's all been worth it. As she leaves, she drapes the pennant over Albert's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You keep looking after Joey and he'll always be looking after you. Albert looks again at the pennant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeant, Seventh Battalion, Imperial Yeomanry. (amazed, to Joey:) You see this, Joey? It's been through an entire war. Albert holds the pennant in wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not stealing it. I'll give it back to him, someday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Early morning. Dad hobbling across the furrows, alone, planting the field by hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DEVON COUNTRY MONTAGE. Albert and Joey are now in a meadow. They trot past the field he plowed, now packed with a strong and sturdy crop, which Ted tends to. The sun is breaking through and Joey starts to run across the field and up a small incline. As both Joey and Albert gain confidence they pick up speed. Albert pushes Joey on, they are going faster and faster, Albert yells with the exhilaration of it all. Joey races flat out across the countryside. Albert hanging on for dear life. Albert and Joey pull up beside a sleek red car. It's Lyons' car, being driven by David Lyons, every inch the expensively- tailored rural gentry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um, I'm the only boy that drives in the village. No one else drives but me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right and this is my dad's car. You're lucky that you're in it. I'm not normally allowed to drive it `cause it's so - Albert urges Joey to go faster, till they're neck and neck beside the car, racing it. David Lyons looks to see Albert and Joey running alongside his car. He feigns disinterest. Albert glances at David, but he's much more interested in the very pretty young woman seated next to David, her hands trying to control her hair, flying in the wind. Forgetting himself momentarily, Albert stares at her, dazzled. The woman turns to David:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he a friend of yours? She smiles at Albert, encouraging him. David Lyons, annoyed, pushes the accelerator down, and the car edges ahead of Joey. But not for long. The sound of the acceleration and Albert's eagerness to impress the young woman make Joey go faster, and again he moves out ahead of the car. The young woman grins at Albert. Up ahead Albert sees that the wall alongside of which he's been racing turns the corner, presenting him and Joey with an obstacle. Albert encourages Joey to go faster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, boy, let's show her how to fly! They head right for the wall, but at the very last moment, Joey balks and comes to a dead standstill, sending Albert sailing over the wall. Back in the car, the girl gasps and covers her mouth, concerned. David says nothing, but allows himself a small smile. On the other side of the wall, Albert stands a bit battered, but unfazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...you're clearly not gonna be a jumper. Thunder starts to rumble ominously in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. Albert and Joey return, driving sheep before them. Angry storm clouds stretch to the horizon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. As Albert leads Joey to the stable, lighting blasts across an angry sky. The rain is falling in torrents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. Another crack of thunder - and a piece of wood in the roof gives way - water gushes in - Dad rushes to support the roof as the wind forces a window open. At that moment, the door suddenly swings open with the violence of the storm, smashing against the wall - Dad and Rosie turn - and there is Harold the goose, who scuttles in without his usual arrogance and hides himself in a corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT Shoo, Harold. Shoo, shoo, shoo! The thunder cracks again and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Albert and Dad walk across the field. Mrs. Narracott digs through the mess. The entire crop is flat - ruined by the storms. The ground squelches beneath their feet. The whole field is a write off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can try planting something else, or we could hire ourselves out to Uncle Bob. Dad doesn't answer. He shakes his head and limps away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How else we gonna pay Mr. Lyons' rent? Ted doesn't turn around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. Mrs. Narracott makes some coffee. Ted sits alone on a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARRACOTT What we gonna do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to believe that God gave each man his fair portion of bad luck. I don't feel that any more. I've had more than my share. (PAUSE) You'll stop loving me, Rose. And I won't blame you when you do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I might hate you more - but I'll never love you less. Then somewhere in the distance, an unfamiliar sound...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. A motorbike rumbles along the lane at huge speed creating a cloud of dust as it goes. The noise of the motorbike is drawing attention from all over the valley. It can be heard fields away and everyone is drawn to this completely unheard of sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. The motorbike whizzes through the village. Heads turn in astonishment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's war! The bike comes to a stop in the market place. The rider takes off his goggles. Men of the village start to flock around the machine, with great curiosity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are at War with Germany. You hear? England is at war with Germany. Shock and amazement. The rider takes off his goggles:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're going to ring the bells at six o'clock - and then never ring them again until the war is over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Everyone across England knows that their lives are about to change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Dawn rises over the farm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN. Albert races to the stables, excited with the campaign pennant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. As Albert enters the stables, he calls out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look smart, Joey lad, it's the Tavistock Fair! Albert opens the doors and stops dead. He looks at the empty stables.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN / YARD. DAY. Albert runs out. He rushes into the kitchen. His mother stares out the window. She has been crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What has he done with him? She says nothing, but her face gives everything away. Albert in a panic turns and runs out into the lane. Mrs. Narracott tears up again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. The market square is full of military men. The Union Jack is flying up the flagpole. A group of girls has gathered to check out the army boys. Eager young men crowd a table staffed by recruiting officers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last name first. First name, middle name, last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is in the square inspecting Joey, knowledgably. He is a handsome, attractive, modest, upper class man. Dad stands beside him. He checks Joey's teeth, his feet and finally, looks him straight in the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take my word for it - finest horse in the parish. Goes like a racer, strong, decent, very fine. Captain Nicholls has immediately connected with Joey and puts him at his ease. SAM PERKINS, a tough sergeant, is physically inspecting Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No curbs, no splints, good feet and teeth. He's as sound as a bell, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how much are you charging, sir - for this strong, decent, and very fine animal?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll give you twenty and not a penny more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty is no good to me, Captain. Thirty five and he's yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't even know how he rides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, he rides... Splendidly. You'll be astonished. I promise you that. (his heart's in his throat, fighting back
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finest horse in all of Devon. Finest horse I ever seen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Albert bursts into the square just in time to see Nicholls and Dad shake hands. Their business concluded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Albert races towards Joey. Ted grabs him. Albert fights to get free. He looks at his father in anger and betrayal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't! You can't, he's mine! I trained him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albert. Albert is hysterical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't have him. He's my horse, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid it's too late, lad. I've just paid thirty guineas for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, I'll get you money. I will, I'll get you money. I'll...I'll work for it! I'll work for it. (TO NICHOLLS:) He won't obey anyone else. He won't be any good in the war, neither. He...he shies at every sound!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Albert snaps to attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if Joey's going, I'm going, too. I'm volunteering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. What's your name, lad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albert, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how old are you, Albert?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nineteen, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that the truth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No sir. But, but I look nineteen and I'm bigger than most nineteen-year- olds, sir! And I'm strong, sir! And I...I'm not afraid of anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't doubt your qualifications, Albert, but the law is very clear about the proper age for soldiering, and your father's done what he had to do. You know that. Thirty guineas isn't nearly enough to purchase a horse as fine as your Joey, I know that. But it's all I've got. Will you lease him to me, Albert, to be my own mount? (he removes his cap,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promise you, man to man, that I'll look after him as closely as you've done, I'll respect him and all the care that you've taken with him. And if I can - I'll return him to your care. Albert looks at him. Although Nicholls speaks with authority he has a kindness which Albert recognizes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now say goodbye. Albert kisses Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right, boy... But at that moment, Sam Perkins pulls Joey away:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, turn it in, eh? That's enough. He's a horse, not a dog. Now, on your way. (TO JOEY) Come on. Nicholls walks away into the crowd. The Sergeant pulls Joey, but Joey does not want to be separated from Albert. His reaction is implacable, reminiscent to the separation from his mother. Perkins leads Joey away. They disappear into the crowd and Rosie is suddenly there. Ted senses her silent judgment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want to lose the farm, Rose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the way you did it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we're at war.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't we just. She looks at Albert. Implacable. Forever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. The recruits march through town under pennants and the strains of a familiar song("The Jolly Plowboy") - it is a song they all know, which means a lot to them - full of soul - a song of harvest or a Celtic hymn, something relating specifically to the lives they have led together. Everyone of every age - everyone in the village knows this song - it is theirs. Nicholls passes in his car and we see those they are leaving behind - cheering - a whole generation of young men is marching off to war. One girlfriend rushes up to kiss her leaving boyfriend. Albert watches Joey, then remembers the campaign pennant dangling from his pocket. He runs up to Joey -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joey... - and tucks the pennant into Joey's halter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here now, I've told you - sling your hook! But Nicholls intervenes from his car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him be, Perkins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't the end. This isn't the end, my brother... I, Albert Narracott, solemnly swear we will be together again. Wherever you are, I will find you. And I will bring you home! And then they are past him, leaving him behind. As Perkins leads Joey across a stone bridge, Albert watches from the bank of the stream. Joey balks one last time - 37.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa. Steady, steady. Steady now, come on. Walk on! Walk on now, come on! - then Perkins leads him away, leaving Albert behind. The very last recruits leave the village - leaving the debris of this army's visit strewn on the square. Like the debris of a party you are already beginning to regret.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Joey is handed off to a groom. Joey is amazed by the scale of the building. Each horse has a large stall and is being tended to assiduously. Joey looks around at the hundreds of men and horses around him and panics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa whoa whoa. Easy easy... He bucks, throwing the groom to the ground, and gallops away. But Perkins cuts him off, grabs his halter, and jerks him back to attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa whoa whoa, Joey! Stop muckin' about, you hear? Yer in the army now, son. He pushes him into his stall, next to Major Stewart's horse, a magnificent black stallion, TOPTHORN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good boy, good boy. Steady steady... Easy. Relax. Easy easy, back up. Joey rears up in his stall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joey - meet Topthorn. Topthorn - this is Joey. Sort out who's in charge between the two of you, you hear? If you want to fight, you get it over with - `cause once we're over there, you're gonna need everything you've got for Fritz! This is the first time that Joey has had to deal with another horse since his mother - the beginning of one of the most important relationships in his life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gently, Perkins. I don't want to sour him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Nicholls passes his gloves and crop to his bat boy who is there to assist him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There'll be nothing gentle about the war, sir. And there'll be nothing gentle about this one either!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand that, Sergeant, but I want him fit and shining. He's my horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir. Nicholls is joined by his friend LIEUTENANT CHARLIE WAVERLY. He is sweet and friendly - upper class but completely benign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scares the living daylights out of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perkins. Glad he's on our side. They're both joined by a tall, confident officer, MAJOR JAMIE STEWART. He sizes up Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not bad. Not bad at all. Still not a patch on my Topthorn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't be so sure. I think he's got potential. He's certainly got the bit between his teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I actually think my Blenheim is faster than the pair of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clear off! He suddenly turns from the joking into the efficient senior officer he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, gentlemen, listen here. Everything tells us the same story, from Waterloo to Omdurman, from Pickett's Charge to the Battle of Mars La Tours - the first attack can and should be the decisive one. Perkins...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No excuses, no mistakes - every horse groomed and fit for presentation! I want a full practice charge tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir. They leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. The whole regiment is gathered. Everybody is in their ceremonial uniform. It all has the feeling of the Changing of the Guard rather than anything related to a real battle. The day is hot, the plains are quiet and beautiful, the gathering is huge, there is a real sense of pride and anticipation. Captain Nicholls, resplendent in full uniform rides Joey out over the vast expanse of the plain. Both Nicholls and Joey are dressed up like something from the last century, out of the Boer War, even the Charge of the Light Brigade. Nicholls is proud and confident. They gather before hundreds of men and horses all lined up to be inspected. Charlie joins them, looking pretty good on Blenheim. Finally, Nicholls and Charlie reach Stewart and Topthorn waiting in position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thought you two had bottled out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As if. Nicholls looks at his friend tolerantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, then, let's see what you two jokers are made of, shall we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is what quiet confidence looks like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll wait for you two at the Duke of York. Nicholls and Stewart and Charlie prepare themselves for the charge. Joey and Topthorn size up to one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over to you, Captain Nicholls. Topthorn bristles at Joey. Everyone is highly charged. The competition between Stewart and Nicholls seems to have been absorbed between the horses. Topthorn and Joey square up for the practice charge like two athletes before a race.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Draw...swords! Nicholls raises his sword. It glints in the summer air. It seems to hang there forever. Every man follows suit. Topthorn and Joey glance at each other, ready to charge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give...point! Every sword is pointed directly ahead at arm's length.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charge!!!! A roar goes up from the men and a deafening pounding of hooves breaks the silence. The huge line of horses start running straight ahead of them. Joey and Topthorn run off at top speed. Dust and earth rise up behind them. Bugles, the deafening thunder of hooves. It is exhilarating. We see the scale of the operation, we enjoy the speed and the splendor of the mass of men and horses. The soldiers shout in glee and excitement. Each man pushes his horse to out-run those around him, Nicholls and Stewart seem locked in mortal combat. Nicholls smiles at Stewart, confidently. Topthorn starts to pull away, ahead of all the other horses in the line. Nicholls pushes Joey on. Topthorn seems too strong, Joey will never catch them. Nicholls is determined not to be beaten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Joey. I know you've got it. Come on, boy! Come on! He pushes Joey on. Joey digs in and finds hidden strength and speed. He starts to catch up with Topthorn and draws along side. Nicholls and Stewart exchange tense looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, boy! Stewart is amazed and pushes Topthorn harder. Now both riders are going at their top speed. They are neck and neck - they fight for every inch of advantage, every fibre of their being invested in the race. Nicholls pushes Joey on and Joey pulls away. Joey inches forward till he is almost a length ahead of Topthorn. The effort is enormous. Nicholls looks back at Stewart, very happy. Stewart's frustration shows. He knows he is beaten. Then suddenly they race over the line. Nicholls spears a ring decorated with a blue ribbon and pulls Joey to a halt. They have crossed the enemy line. Nicholls is ecstatic. Topthorn comes to Joey's side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa. Whoa. Nicholls laughs, grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice of you to turn up. The horses are nose to nose, snorting, we sense the heat, the exertion. Topthorn and Joey are brought together by the effort. We sense Topthorn's newly minted respect for Joey. And Joey is no soft touch - he slightly holds his head up in victory, letting Topthorn know that he knows he won. The other horses come charging in. There is a real sense of achievement and congratulation amongst the regiment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got speed...I'll give him that. But has he got stamina?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has everything. The two men enjoy the moment of rivalry and the exhilaration of it all. The two horses, face to face rub against each other for the first time. A bond has been formed...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Stewart enters. A phonograph plays "Roses of Picardy." The walls are decorated with etchings of famous battles, and a large map of Western Europe that depicts how the English troops are crossing the channel to confront the Germans near Belgium. Nicholls is writing a letter - though actually at this moment, he is making a little pencil drawing of Joey to enclose with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you up to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm writing a letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a picture in it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's to the boy who owned Joey. I want to show him how wonderful he's looking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before we take him away across the Channel to face a million Germans guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Before that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 4 a.m. start tomorrow - travelling with the Dragoon Guards and the Royals. Transport detachment - they'll need to be at the docks at 5 am. Check all kit. Battle orders: no polishing - buttons, helmet buckles, stirrup irons - let `em all go dull. I want nothing to flash in the sun and give us away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. As Stewart leaves, he passes Charlie. He casually acknowledges him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Charlie checks his new cap in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think of the cap? He shows the bright red lining to Nicholls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silk lining. I quite like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure it's going to make a lot of difference to the Germans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I don't know about that. Think about it - you're a Boche, just working out which of two chaps to shoot - and you thought - "Good Lord - one of them really is wearing a very stylish cap indeed!" You might shoot the other one instead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or, alternatively, think - "I fancy that cap" and kill you first of all. Pause. Charlie removes the cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hadn't thought of that. Nicholls returns to his sketch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FRANCE. Three hundred horses and their charges in a slow march in the middle of the most pristine French countryside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FRANCE - 1914, QUIEVRECHAIN EXT. ROAD. DAY. Nicholls and Stewart and Charlie ride on a smooth road past a series of posts screened with cloth. They're silhouetted against the setting sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. The regiment are tense and nervous as they gingerly make their way along the country road. Topthorn and Joey sense the grim change of atmosphere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. They are in woodland above a plain stretching for miles. A small table has been taken out for Stewart and his officers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - a turbaned Indian with a magnificent moustache dressed in ceremonial garb - explains the lines of battle on a map.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAJOR SINGH That is our target - the German 11th Division - at the moment bivouacked three miles to the east of the Menin Road. We have been watching them and they have pitched tents for the night and lit cooking fires. Knock them out - and we could slide in behind the German lines and come at them from the South at Geluveld.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Numbers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAJOR SINGH About six hundred. Infantry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twice our size...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In regiments of horse and men, the advantage is ours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAJOR SINGH And we have surprise on our side. But the sooner we move, the better - we have no assurance they'll still be there tomorrow morning. Our officers just have a second to take in the news. The day has suddenly arrived. The day they have worked for, for so long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. Good. So - today it is. Charlie - tell the men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salisbury formation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salisbury formation. We'll charge through them and secure the ground behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAJOR SINGH The grass to the left is taller than we are - it's perfect cover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent work, Sergeant Major. Time spent on reconnaissance is rarely wasted. As Stewart departs:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Singh. (CALLING AFTER) Jamie! Nicholls catches up to Stewart, concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have no idea we're coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not having scruples, are you, Jim?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I understand the surprise is everything. But if it must be done, let's do it quickly. Nicholls notices Charlie nervously attending his horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you alright, Charlie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never been better. Literally, never better. We worry for him - he is afraid. Stewart rides through the lines astride Topthorn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prepare to mount! Mount! As the cry is echoed throughout the regiment, Nicholls accepts Joey from an attending soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Standley. (TO JOEY) Hey, Joey. My bonny boy. You're all right, aren't you, Joey? Hey? Nicholls takes the red campaign pennant from his pocket and threads it through Joey's reins. Minutes later - Stewart addresses the men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentleman. It is an honour to ride beside you. Make the Kaiser rue the day he dared to cross swords with us. Let every man make himself, his King, his country, and his fallen comrades proud! Be brave. Fear God. Honor the King!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in unison shout) Fear God. Honor the King!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Cut to an elegant field of tall grass, waving in the gentle breeze. Then suddenly three hundred men seem to rise out of it. They are in fact our soldiers, mounting their horses - but the horses are invisible in the height of the grass. Stewart gives a signal. We see the intense anticipation on his face. He takes out his sabre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Draw swords! The men draw their sabres in silence. The birds chirping, oblivious. Then Nicholls just turns to his two friends and almost whispers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck, my friends. He pats Joey's side. And then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forward, to walk! Walk...march! The regiment begins moving through the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forward to canter! Canter...march! The men start to float over the grass - swept along by their invisible horses, until... Suddenly they emerge from the tall grass - the immense power of the galloping horses - silence explodes into a violent crashing of hooves. The noise is immense, swords are flying in the air. Hundreds of horses racing towards the German encampment. On the German side, TWO SOLDIERS wake to the sound of hoofbeats. They pull their tent flap aside to find the invincible charge coming towards them. The Germans are totally unprepared. We see them scramble back towards tents, rush towards their guns - one man pulling up his trousers rushes for cover. One German drops some dirty dishes into a wash pot, screaming:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kavallerie! Topthorn and Joey race each other like a rerun of their practice on Salisbury Plain. The swords and uniforms glint in the sun, the German troops look terrified - some run in panic, others prepare to stand their ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! The British head in for the kill, the men scream battle cries with sheer exhilaration. We see the horses at close quarters running with all their might. Nicholls and Stewart yell as they approach the enemy. The surprise attack is a huge success. The first row of unprepared Germans are falling... The regiment sweeps through the encampment, cutting down soldiers and driving the rest in a panicked retreat to the tree line. But then we see, in the shadows of the forest behind the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A machine gun. No, a line of machine guns - at least twenty guns, sandbagged apart - the logical, new, modern defence of a garrison. In an instant, the fleeing Germans have manned the guns. All now firing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The noise of the blast of bullets drowns out everything else. A score of men and horses are suddenly on the ground, it happens almost so quickly Joey and Topthorn don't realize anything's wrong and find themselves racing straight towards the guns. The bullets keep coming, now suddenly half of the regiment are on the ground. Horse after horse races past the guns into the woods...all of them now riderless. Nicholls watches helplessly as one of the barrels swings towards him. His face goes slack as he realizes he is about to die. A moment later, Joey runs on - we pan up to see he is running on riderless - he has not realized that Nicholls is gone. The bullets whizz around his head, but he still runs directly ahead. We would always know him by the red pennant Nicholls tied on his saddle. Joey is now running through the German lines. No one bothers to attack him as the German's concentrate their efforts on the cavalry behind him. The line of machine guns fire as one, decimating the horses and their riders. Joey leaps and dances nimbly through the German ranks, but suddenly rears up in the confusion, surrounded by Germans. Near him, surviving English officers are hauled from their horses. Stewart wheels back around on Topthorn, sabre in hand. But he, too, is quickly surrounded by several Germans with their rifles trained on him. A furious GERMAN OFFICER storms over, speaks perfect English:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Did you think that a garrison on open ground would go undefended? Look at yourself! Who do you think you are?!! Stewart looks at the Officer - at the guns that surround him - and throws down his sabre, stabbing it into the ground. The Germans take Stewart from Topthorn. Around them, the fields are littered with dead soldiers and horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Topthorn appears disoriented and frightened. Suddenly, he rears up and bolts from his new German handler, galloping over to Joey. The horses briefly nuzzle, but both rear up again as they are separated and led past a young German soldier, GUNTHER. He zeroes in on them, the finest horses. A slightly more JUNIOR OFFICER approaches the outraged senior officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . What do we do with the horses?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they're injured, shoot them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the others, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others you round up and take to base camp - they will pull guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll never get fancy horses like these to pull guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then shoot them also. Gunther, the young private, now standing behind them, interjects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir - perhaps we could use some of them with the ambulances - to get the injured men off the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will they take the harness?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to try, sir. The officers move away - that's enough talk about horses...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Gunther is now with Joey and Topthorn. Near a wooden ambulance - which is like a giant wagon to carry humans. He is with MICHAEL, a very young soldier, his brother - possibly as young as 14.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Gunther lifts a heavy pulling harness - and tries to get Topthorn into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It won't work - they're cavalry
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't get the harness on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Michael. Topthorn balks violently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa, whoa. Easy, now, easy now, Englishman... Whoa, whoa, whoa. Easy now, easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gunther! It's hopeless - we can't help them. And suddenly Joey moves up and presents himself, with his strange self assurance and self sacrifice. And instinct for survival. He sniffs the harness and places his head through it, which helps to calm Topthorn enough that Gunther can slip the collar onto the big black horse. Gunther turns to Joey, impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, well, look at you. Whoever taught you this has just saved your life. Gunther spots the red ribbon in Joey's saddle, removes it, folds it, and places it in his pocket.
