Later - Gunther and Michael are returning from the battlefield with Topthorn and Joey, pulling an ambulance with British and German wounded. Amongst the wounded, we see a hand gripping a battered, silk lined hat. It is Waverly, wounded but alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DEVON. DAY. Si Easton lets himself in through the gate. Ted pulls up turnips from their three acre crop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Rosie, just across a furrow, is also engaged in the harvest. It's hard work. Si holds a parcel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello the farm!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking up, wiping her
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Si Easton! Albert passes carrying a crate laden with turnips, but pulls up short when he hears:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was at the post office and while I was there, Mrs. Allen said a parcel had come for Albert, from the, from the, from over there - and I thought I could go up that way in the morning. And - here it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, who'd be sending me a parcel over there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, open it and see. Albert opens the parcel and pulls out a leather sketchbook...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a sketchbook... (gasp of realization) That's Captain Nicholls' sketchbook! See that? That's a picture of Joey!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a picture of Joey. Well, I never!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there's a letter...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, go on then, go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. (READING) "Dear Albert Narracott. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Captain Nicholls, who died...Captain Nicholls, who died in action today left you this. Yours, Sergeant Sam Perkins. Si Easton drops his head guiltily. Rosie catches this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You weren't to know it was bad news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was riding Joey when he died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know that he was riding him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "In action," it says. Everybody falls silent. Albert goes to the fence and looks down at the sketches of Joey. Rosie looks at her son, her heart breaking for him. Dad returns to the harvest without a word. Albert looks off to the horizon and - over there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- A step stool. Michael mounts the stool next to Joey and Topthorn, removes their harnesses and carries them across the road. Michael slips and falls into the mud. Gunther dashes over and pulls him up just before a military convoy pulls into the camp, running over the tack. The BASE CAMP OFFICER appears on a motorbike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Gentlemen! We move forward to the frontline tonight. Full marching orders. Get moving! As the soldiers hop to their orders, the officer turns to -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schroeder! Schroeder! Both Michael and Gunther turn to him. But it's Gunther the Officer wants to talk to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not you - you. Come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Gunther picks up the dropped harnesses as he approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm keeping you here. You are best with the horses and we need to move the camp quickly if the enemy continue to push through from the west.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're pushing through?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm told. We will move later when we find where the horses are needed most.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Perhaps I can keep my brother here with me, he's also very good with horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no no. Not necessary. (TO MICHAEL) Get moving. We leave tonight. He walks away. Gunther is stricken by the news, but Michael is excited. As he leads Joey past his brother:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right, Gunther. Gunther can't really speak. Michael is just a boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. Soldiers are lifting up their equipment - gathering - moving in the same direction. In a quiet tent, a few last soldiers are packing. And there are Gunther and Michael, packing together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are not going. I'll tell them you are only fourteen, that you're a boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father signed me in. He knew my age -and so do they.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The process of packing is their way of coping with the shock. Gunther is folding one of Michael's shirts. Michael takes it back...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother obviously never taught you how to fold a shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course she did. I just wasn't listening. But you need to listen now! I promised her, I made her a solemn promise, that you would be safe with me. With me, Michael!! He leans close to Michael, talking in almost a whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll never make a head count. There are too many of us. You can stay here - slip underneath the bed - until they move out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what? Michael carries on with his packing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gunther, it will be fine. And when all the machines break down and they call up the horses, I'll see you at the front. We'll be together again. And now the case is packed. Gunther heads to the tent opening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gunther... Looking round, the tent is now empty. The moment to leave has come. Gunther pulls the red pennant from his pocket and follows Michael out of the tent to where the soldiers are lining up in the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm giving this to you. For luck. Gunther ties the pennant to the back of Michael's pack as he forms up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To keep you safe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Michael smiles at him and begins to march. Marching towards Ypres, on the Western Front.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Im schnellschritt! Marsch...links! Zwei, drei, vier! We settle on young Michael - in line - he passes Gunther. He remains eager. But it is goodbye. These soldiers moving into the darkness and towards death. Gunther looks on - tears in his eyes. The two horses are uneasy - sensing tension. A few minutes later - Gunther grabs a saddle and throws it onto Joey's back. Back to the soldiers. Suddenly we see the galloping legs of two horses. They whip past the back of the line of marching soldiers. It's clear what is happening - Gunther is on Topthorn - and has hold of Joey, on a loose rope, galloping beside him. Gunther, galloping along the line of soldiers, spots what he is looking for, a red pennant unfurled and flapping in the wind, tied onto Michael's pack. Gunther speeds toward him. This was his plan all along. And in an instant he is beside him and without Michael ever realizing, he suddenly finds his arms and legs akimbo, as he is yanked out of the line and dragged along the ground, desperately close to Joey's pounding hooves. Michael looks at the soldiers beside him - he looks at the skyline of violence ahead...but before he can decide, he feels his brother's arm - pulling him upwards. And now, the two of them are fully on Topthorn. They leave a jumble of soldiers in their wake as the officers try to restore order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back in line! Line!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER. Michael now rides Joey, following Gunther on Topthorn. The brothers look at each other - can't believe what they have done - Michael is following his brother, swept along, doesn't know if it is right. And Michael and Joey and Gunther and Topthorn charge on to freedom. They spot a lonely house and burst past a line with some drying clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . As they ride, they grab civilian shirts and jackets and trousers, the clothes pegs pinging off and falling to the ground. And on they ride - though all too soon day starts to break in the far distance. They see a very dilapidated windmill. They aim for it as the sun begins to seriously break over the horizon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN. They reach the windmill. It feels very unused. The machinery of the windmill creaks in the dawn. The brothers untether the horses, careful now that it is light outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm hungry. Did you bring food?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Michael fingers the pennant on Joey's reins. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will Father be ashamed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He will pretend to be. Maybe at first he will be. But in the end, he will be glad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And us? What about us? Gunther looks at him - but doesn't reply. As Michael removes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was ready to go. I was proud to go. (after a beat, in a very
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to go. Later - They sit in silence, waiting for sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The food in Italy is good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about the women?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not as good as the food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because...they've eaten too much of the food?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are too young for war. And you're too young for women! Gunther laughingly pushes him over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't feel so young. Not anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to sleep - we have a big night of riding ahead. Goodnight, Michael. He jokingly strokes Michael's cheek. Michael swats him away, but as he settles in the hay:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Night night, Gunther.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK. Gunther and Michael sleep. Suddenly something awakens Joey. He stirs and then rises. Hear the sound of engines and see lights through the slats sweeping across Joey's face. Michael and Gunther are stirring in their sleep as we hear a car and several motorcycles approaching. Head-lamps filter through the cracks in the windmill walls stabbing the brothers awake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hei! In die windmuhle! The boys spring up, speaking in terrified whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go, go, go...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.

direction.raw_text: . They race up a nearby ladder, but Michael stumbles against a table, upsetting some gear. It clatters loudly. They cower as they hear boots tromping up the steps outside. Then the windmill doors are thrown open, pinning them in the bright headlights of the vehicles. As they're marched out, we see what they see: A German car - two motorcycles. Six Germans, including the officer who was in charge of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schroeder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mistake? He's offering an excuse, but -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A promise. The officer accepts this grimly, nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ja... As the boys are taken away, he lights a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. Through the turning arms of the windmill, we glimpse the double execution. Four rifles fire - flashes of the soldiers shooting - the bodies on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Complete stillness in the empty countryside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. There are Joey and Topthorn, still waiting. And then suddenly - the doors of the windmill creak. The two horses turn, immensely aware of the break in the silence. The door opens a little - and we see, reflected in Joey's eye, a very delicate, beautiful, thirteen-year-old country girl (EMILIE). She stares at the horses. They stare straight back at her. And she walks straight out again, closing the big door behind her. Joey and Topthorn settle for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Time transition - Joey and Topthorn are in a slightly different place - and the door opens again. It is the same little girl - but this time she comes in carrying two buckets full of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A small humble farmhouse - and round it, small fields, planted with different fruit crops. We see an old man (GRANDFATHER), burdened with a basket of berries heading back towards the farmhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: far in the distance the STORM OF WAR is in the sky. He enters the kitchen - which is rough, but full of the paraphernalia of jam-making - jars, sieves, pectin, sugar. Emilie is at the sink, washing berries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandpere. He heads towards the side-board, dumps the two bags and lifts the first handful of fruits on to the counter. She empties her clean berries into a bowl. Notes the explosions outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's closer today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wind plays tricks with the noise - it's moving away from us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can hear it, Grandpere, and there is no wind. You shouldn't lie to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here. There is no wind here. But over there - a wind so strong it will lift you off the ground...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You lie about everything. You say you aren't worried but it's clear you are. I know the war is approaching but you say, "Oh, it's just a trick of the wind." He retrieves a bottle of medicine from the mantle.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A SOUND CAUSES HIM TO LOOK OUT ACROSS THE FARM --

direction.raw_text: Did I say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You started lying when Mama and Papa went away. She pours a load of sugar into a bowl with the fruit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're dead. But you won't say so. Do you think I'll die if you tell me the truth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth is - He feeds her a spoonful of the medicine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - you should speak to your elders with respect. She sticks her wet finger in the sugar and sucks it to help with the taste of the medicine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you tell me the truth about the war, I will tell you the truth about the big horses I've been keeping in the windmill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (standing, putting his hands on his hips) Now - who is the one telling lies!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SAME. Grandfather looks stunned as he paces in front of JOEY AND TOPTHORN - who stand in the small courtyard outside the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the windmill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. They were standing in the windmill waiting for Don Quixote. This is Francois (Joey) and this is Claude (Topthorn).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I named them after two boys who broke my heart last Summer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They must belong to someone. Horses like this don't just appear from a fairy-tale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes - I know, Grandpere. They are not unicorns - so I will be fair and wait -- one day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emilie... Emilie...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if no one comes to get them by night-time, then they belong to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emilie. Look at me. You cannot ride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother used to tell me how my bones would give way with the slightest bump or fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. That's right. So it is settled? She kisses his cheek -- GRANDFATHER (CONT'D) Good girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but then calmly leads the horses back to the windmill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will only be settled when I decide which one to ride first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's - Over my dead body!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least I won't have long to wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . That is the end of the conversation as far as she is concerned.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: WE SEE THAT SHE IS HESITANT WITH THEM

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Emilie is with the horses in the little stable at the end of the courtyard - a bit away from the farm house - she is feeding them out of a bucket - not very nice gruel.... WE SEE THAT SHE IS HESITANT WITH THEM - that she has spent no time around horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was in love with a boy called Francois - who had your lovely eyes. (TO CLAUDE) Unfortunately he was in love with a girl called Marie, who had your teeth. She fell for a boy called Claude - who broke my heart. And who I intend to marry one day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Grandfather watches Emilie from inside the house as he makes jam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Eyes on me. No talking. Outside, Emilie has fashioned two jumps. The big one for Joey and a little demonstration obstacle for herself. She leads Joey to a starting point about 30 yards in front of some crates supporting a stick about four feet off the ground. The red pennant hangs from the stick. Joey stands quietly as Emilie hobbles to the big jump, making a jumping gesture with her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Today we learn to jump. Did you know the French cleared one meter eighty- five at the Paris Olympics to win the gold medal? Today we will beat that record. Grandfather chuckles. Emilie indicates the larger barrier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is your jump. When I call you....be very brave and leap over it. She claps, but Joey doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leap over it! Watch me. She turns to her demonstration jump and easily steps over her six-inch high barrier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now it's your -- She turns to find Joey already stepping over her mini-jump, stopping in front of her. He's only interested in the apple in her hand. She takes a bite herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emilie returns Joey to the starting line and runs back behind the big jump. From behind her back she produces three big carrots dripping soil. Joey's ears perk and he takes off quickly but at the last moment veers right and passes between the two jumps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Grandfather is watching through the window as he prepares his strawberry jams. He laughs and goes back to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aware she's being watched, she slings the carrots over her shoulder, frustrated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER. Joey slowly emerges from the barn with Emilie out in front leading him with one hand. In the other hand, she carries a small wooden step ladder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't think we can do it. But we will show him, won't we? Emilie unfolds the ladder beside Joey and shakily starts climbing to the top of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Her voice shaking) No need to be afraid. (Emilie looking down at how far off the ground
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are...very tall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Before she can swing her leg over Joey's back -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll kill yourself. Emilie turns, and there, blocking the hurdle, now standing hands on hips, is Grandfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only if you get in my way to make me fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh please, come off the ladd--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: from far down the road. Grandfather looks. Emilie turns to look too. Two trucks led by a German motorcycle are approaching the farm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Find somewhere to hide them. And do it quickly!!! As Emilie races off with the horses, Grandfather pushes over the jumps and jams the pennant into his pocket. The bikes arrive first, just missing Emilie as she leads the horses behind the house. The trucks arrive, pull round - one of the soldiers in the front jumps out and opens the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Halt! Und aussteigen! The people - 20 of them, all seeming to be poor French peasants, mainly women, move out of the truck. As they walk past, they avoid the eye of the Grandfather, who approaches the soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Bonnard - this is my land. Why are you here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Food for the soldiers at the front. Everyone must give their share. And suddenly we see what is going to happen - the 20 peasants spread out and move through the field - with either bags, or using the aprons they wear - picking all the fruits - at just the moment all the work has brought forth fruit - and the new year's crop is ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Raspberries, black-currants, gooseberries. In a few minutes, everything he lives by will be gone. Watching from his car and calmly smoking a cigar is BRANDT, the officer in charge of the unit. Cut to the fields - the aprons and baskets are getting full. They move through the rows of fruit like a plague of locusts. Back to the Grandfather - and out of the house comes Emilie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are taking everything. Where are the horses? Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What horses? The sound of jars breaking draws Grandfather and Emilie into the kitchen, where the Germans continue to raid their other supplies. One German picks up waterbath canner -- inspecting it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave it if you don't know what it's for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pot is a pot. We'll find some use for it. Sir, where's the livestock? Brandt sits quietly, casually using his finger to scoop jam from an open jar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I make jam. We have no animals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But there's fresh hay in your barn. Emilie enters, overhearing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We use it to replace the mattress stuffings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her grandfather?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are her parents?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're dead. They died. The German nods and is about to take his leave, putting the pot back where he found it, when a clumping noise from somewhere in the house begins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wind. It plays tricks in the attic. Brandt licks his finger and tests:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An old house creaks. (TO EMILIE) Go - close the shutters. Emilie runs out of the room. The soldier picks up the medicine bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's sickly, no?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you or any of your friends harm her, as old as I am, I will kill you. The soldier looks shocked and then begins to laugh. He slaps the medicine flask into Grandfather's chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I was going to give you back your pot. But now I'm going to keep it. For soup. He slings the huge pot he had put back up on his shoulder and leaves the house with the other soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We will be back in the new season. As the Germans leave, we cut to the upstairs bedroom where Emilie lies curled up on the bed - and there, standing on either side of the bed - are the two horses. They look huge in the tiny room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATE THAT NIGHT. The sound of shells exploding. A huge bombardment somewhere in the deep distance. But much closer than before. The distant, malicious giants of war growl. It is like a lightning storm on the horizon. The kitchen has been emptied. The war has finally come to them - and we can see it on Emilie's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me what happened to them. To my mother and father. Grandfather doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said you would tell me how they died. On my birthday. And tomorrow's my birthday! They died fighting, didn't they? But when the soldiers
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finally turns to face him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - you do nothing. You are a coward, aren't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Yes. It was your parents who were brave. I make jams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you've never done a brave thing in your life? He eases himself into a chair and shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe there are different ways to be brave. Did you know the French have the best carrier pigeons? And this could be the difference in the war - our messages getting through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to hear about the birds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are released at the front and told to go home - this is all they know. But to get there they must fly over a war. Can you imagine such a thing? Here you are flying over so much pain and terror - and you know you can never look down. You have to look forward or you'll never get home. I ask you - what could be braver than that? Emilie sheds a single tear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN. Grandfather enters the barn, strokes Topthorn's nose as he passes. He sweeps aside a rug from the barn floor, to reveal a trap door. Then, he opens it. Now from out of the trap door, he lifts a big ungainly object, covered in another rug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MORNING. Emilie comes down the stairs as Grandfather waits proudly by the stove. She stops when she sees the OBJECT COVERED BY THE RUG.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A present. Emilie moves toward the object that is covered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you have not bought me a disgusting dress that I then have to wear like last year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was disgusting?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I looked like an ugly nun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Then she stops herself and turns to Grandfather with a parental rebuke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me your hand. (she takes it in hers) Grandpere, we have no money. When the war is over, then you can buy me jewels and carriages. The grandfather smiles and gives Emily a hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything you say, my sweet one. Anything-you-say! You are, of course, the boss. It's just an old thing I found - don't worry yourself - leave it, I'll put it back. He leaves the room. Now Emilie is alone and she can't help it when she brings her eyes back to the object covered by the rug. She looks back over her shoulder to make sure she's not being watched and then lifts one corner of the rug. Her face explodes with a gorgeous smile. She pulls off the rug that is covering the big thing and...it is a gorgeous old saddle. She runs her hand along the saddle -- can hardly believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . JUST BEYOND THE FARMHOUSE. NEAR THE WINDMILL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Grandfather helps to swing Emilie up and into the saddle. All at once, the Grandfather's charity evaporates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was your mother's. I hid it, so as not to encourage you. Emilie, I want you to ride very slowly, very carefully. And promise me you won't go far -- EMILIE Of course. Okay, I promise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To the top of the hill and straight back again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promise. Emilie unties her hair and tosses the red pennant to Grandfather, releasing her hair to spill down her back and shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My hero. She sets off on Joey - and quickly spurs him to a gallop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly...slowly... She rides - past the windmill - and then over the top of a nearby hill - she speeds over it and out of sight. Back to the hill - a sudden change of mood. An empty shot. No movement, no returning girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emilie! Cut again to the top of the hill, then back to the Grandfather, very worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emilie! Topthorn suddenly rears up - and charges off following, sensing danger. Grandfather starts to run in the direction of the hill. Topthorn charging over the brow of the hill. The Grandfather running - out of breath. He hears an indistinct scream from Emilie! He reaches the top of the hill - comes over the brow - and there is not the fallen body of Emilie, which he has been fearing, but a brutal line of German soldiers - and motorbikes. It is like a line of Indians in a Western - total, alien fear. And there amongst them is Emilie, astride a panicked Joey, surrounded by soldiers. Another one holds Topthorn, who bucks and rears, but to no avail. Grandfather starts down the hill towards his granddaughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME The Germans are moving through the horses they have gathered. Emilie, unhorsed, tries to get to Joey, who is being roughly led away by a German soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Let go of me! No!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Grandfather grabs her. She is screaming. He tries to calm her down. Joey is tied up as is Topthorn. Emilie is kicking and screaming - but also desperately short of breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is my granddaughter! Emilie, stop! Don't hurt her, please! Don't hurt her. A soldier roughly shoves Emilie at him. Brandt approaches. Emilie screams at him, in tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't need them! There are so many others! Emilie is still sobbing. Grandfather hugs her - in horror that she is now struggling so hard for breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, take the bigger one and leave the smaller one. You are breaking my granddaughter's heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The war has taken everything from everyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What will happen to them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They will pull artillery until they
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Francois!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - or until the war is over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will never be over!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have your answer then. The motorbikes start up and drive off. The Grandfather hugging tiny Emilie as she coughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The Germans disappear up the lane leaving the old man and the child bereft in the bitter cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER. Two grooms trail Brandt, leading Joey and Topthorn toward a makeshift corral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heiglemann - these are yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look strong - should last a month or two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is an unprepossessing, chubby man. He marvels at Topthorn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are beautiful. But then he looks to the other horses penned nearby, haggard and weak. He turns to Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a pity they found you. He takes the leads of the pair of them. He sighs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Such a pity... In a strange way, there are many humans Joey meets, but also just one, the spirit of goodness and consideration for animals, joined by little echoes throughout the film. And then they go over a ridge - and we suddenly see the explanation of Friedrich's comment. The road they can see below them is the main through road of the area - and it is a scene of horse horror - huge, massive guns and cannons and artillery being dragged by teams of horses that are in a terrible condition. For Joey and Topthorn, this is a moment like when soldiers arrived to liberate the prisoners who had been kept in Changi prison by the Japanese during World War 2. They have never seen horses in this condition. You can see in their eyes the confusion. This is a whole different world, where horses can turn into creatures that look like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . And it is also a vision of their future. This may be the moment the mighty Topthorn begins to lose hope. For Joey it is another level of knowledge - another mighty thing he will fight through - because he always fights through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Friedrich leads Joey and Topthorn in the wake of THE HUGE MORSER - an elaborate 15 ton monstrosity with a six inch bore. It takes a team of six horses to haul it with a dozen men pushing from behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pull together! A soldier calls from the front of the heavy cannon - pulled by a particularly wretched group of horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Halt! Halt! Stop! Lower down the hill, Friedrich waves down the rest of the column.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop! Stop! At the front of the Morser, one of the lead horses collapses - he will never get up again. Brandt steps up, pulls a revolver out of his pocket and shoots the horse dead. It has come to this. Joey, Topthorn, and all the other horses are spooked by the pistol shot. Brandt shouts to Friedrich from the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heiglemann, bring up another one!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heiglemann, bring up another horse!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That one! Friedrich begins leading Joey up the hill, but -- BRANDT (CONT'D) No, no. The big black one! Friedrich hauls Topthorn, hesitantly, while Joey watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . As he reaches Brandt:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a good horse, sir. But if you move him up to the heavy gun, he will be no use at all. Prince is already losing condition. His leg, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have given them names?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should never give a name to anything you are certain to lose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His leg is not good enough, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Private, you will do as you are told. (CALLING OFF) Hook him up. Friedrich has no choice but as he starts to lead Topthorn, Joey rears up and escapes his groom. He gallops up the hill to the gun - offering himself up to save Topthorn. It is his "Tale of Two Cities" moment - giving up his life to save his friend. He bucks and rears. Friedrich turns to Brandt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As you see, sir, this one is stronger. Brandt takes up Friedrich, and Joey's, offer -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hook him up. As Joey is hooked to the gun, he looks back to Friedrich who leads Topthorn back down the hill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER. The convoy struggles up the hill. Joey feels the dead weight of the gun. These are several tons of cast iron - almost dwarfing the horses. Friedrich notices. Together, this grim circus struggles along the pot-holed country road in the rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Joey leads the team up the incline. Each step is an immense effort. The going, over rough scree, is very tough indeed. It is very difficult for Joey to get a foothold on the loose ground, but his experience in Dartmoor comes into play and although he almost loses his balance several times he stays upright and hauls the cannon - Fitzcarraldo-like - over the hill. We follow his progress step by step. Friedrich watches anxiously. Soldiers strain at the sides of the gun. One throws boards under the wheels to aid in traction. As they reach the top of the hill it almost seems the effort is too much, the cannon always in danger of rolling back. Joey finally staggers over the top - it feels as though the tethers are going to snap with the strain - but at last the cannon reaches the peak, the crest of the hill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Soldiers scurry around the giant gun, preparing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Halt! Halt! Take the horses away!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shell! Friedrich observes with Topthorn as a giant shell is carried to the gun's breech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And load! The men wrestle it into place -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back! Case! - and secure it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Position! The barrel of the giant gun ratchets upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And...fire! The shell explodes from the barrel. And then from another. And another. For the first time we see the big picture - the line of assembled cannons of which they were just one tiny part.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Each gun recoils violently as they shoot their shells into oblivion - as soon as one shell is fired another is loaded - the noise is deafening - the line seemingly endless - an obscene production line of death. This is what the horses have been feeding - this massive merciless thing. Smoke wafts from the guns as we see the explosions in the distance. The sound of the explosions takes us to -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. Explosions light the dirty faces of British boys in uniform, one after the next. Each light fading out before the next great blast illuminates another anonymous face -then another - and then another - and then ALBERT. Hold on him for extra moments before he fades completely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EARLY DAWN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FRANCE - 1918, THE SOMME With the barrage lifted, the British soldiers that are huddled in a low sub-trench, are ordered back on the line. Andrew Easton is with Albert and he's shaken and terrified. A far cry from the happy young boy we knew. A gruff sergeant (SERGEANT MARTIN) walks the trench with a bucket and each soldier puts in their valuables and personal belongings. One a lighter, some money, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valuables in the bucket, lads. If you live, you'll get them back. If you live, you'll get them back. Good lads. Albert and Andrew move down the trench in a line of soldiers who are given ammo belts and grenades. Albert gets his grenades and walks further along the trenches. We follow him in real time as he passes a bunch of soldiers who are kneeling in the ankle deep water, a PADRE is giving them communion. The deafening noise of shelling all around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's a drill, Albie. Maybe it's a drill like last time. We keep following Albert's progress in real time - further on there is a post box where they all put their final letters home in identical green envelopes. We see Albert's letter addressed to "Ted and Rose Narracott" in Devon. He posts it in a battered metal post box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . An officer approaches:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love letter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my business. It is David - Lyon's son - now in charge of this small group of men. Still arrogant - looking older than Albert in his uniform - and clearly enjoying his superior rank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear you and your mate were doing bird imitations again. You gonna write a letter to your horse? Albert ignores him. Andrew can't help but giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After you find your horse, I've lost my needle in a haystack, and I could use some help. David takes up a bucket and walks down the line of soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything valuable. Anyone who comes back gets to share it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay here. Albert follows David down the trench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember that day me and Joey raced you in your car?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember you somersaulting through the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who was that girl you were with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was a girl? Albert nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was. Don't you remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was just some girl, I suppose. I don't recall which one. I do remember you falling on your bum in a ditch. Andrew laughs amiably. David points to him, smirking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see? Always entertaining, Narracott, I'll give you that. As David walks on, Andrew smiles at Albert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did that? You fell on your bum? Albert leaves without answering. Andrew keeps smiling until a large shell explodes nearby. Troops surge towards their ladders as officers scream indistinct orders. Now David leads his troop through the trenches to the front line where they stop, lean against the enemy-side wall nervously and wait - each man in private contemplation. Sergeant Martin moves along the lines, pushing men forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be ready! Be ready! Let's go, men, get ready to go! Get ready to move out! Stay in position! David calls out from atop a trench ladder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold your nerve, boys. Remember, it's not far to go. There's a way through. (he moves down the line) Run fast, keep your wits about you, keep your eyes open and God and the King will keep an eye on you. Company will fix bayonets! Fix bayonets! The echo of `fix bayonets' goes down the line - and every man fixes the brutal shining bayonet to the end of his gun. Then Albert turns to Andrew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what it reminds me of out there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That bloody impossible lower field the day me and Joey plowed it. Best day of my life that was and you were there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this here is the worst day of my life, about to begin, and you're here cheering me on. Us two, always. And him. He nods at David Lyons, who gives instructions to another soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once you're in no man's land, go to the flanks. Stay on the flanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. David turns to Albert and Andrew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, boys, come on. To the ladder!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stick close to the gentry, that's our ticket, yeah? We have the pluck but they have the luck. They both smile. And then the fear takes over again. Andrew particularly feels as though he is on the very edge now. David urges them forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You, too, Narracott. (TO ANDREW) And you, too. Andrew and Albert pass by the bucket. They throw some valuables in. But a moment later, Albert goes back to the bucket and pulls something out - a worn piece of paper - he unfolds it - it is the little sketch that Captain Nicholls drew of Joey the night before they left for France. He slips it inside his shirt, next to his heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, on your ladders, boy. On your ladders. In you go, in you go. That's it. Andrew turns towards a ladder. As fate and placement would have it - he is first in line. He puts his foot on the ladder, when suddenly the Sergeant stops him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to your sergeant! He pulls Andrew aside, speaking so that everyone can hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If anybody turns back, if any one of our boys come running towards you - you take this rifle and you shoot them dead. Do you understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir! The sergeant pushes in on Andrew, private and intense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you understand me? Do you understand what I'm telling you, son? You take this rifle and you shoot them dead. Understand? Andrew looks ready to cry, but manages to nod. Albert turns to him, only to be pushed back by the sergeant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up there, son. Up your ladder. Up your ladder to your work! Albert looks nervously back at Albert, comforting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's good. Andrew, it's good. Andrew! Nobody's retreating today. Andrew! Andrew! Nobody. Is retreating. Today. The COMMANDER arrives, checks the time on his AIDE's watch, mounts his ladder and blows a whistle to signal the charge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: plays as the men go over the top. David now heads up the ladder first. Gun fire overhead, Albert steels himself, then hauls himself over the top, followed by the next man and the next.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Immediately machine gun fire whistles past, we hear the screams of the first men who are shot. We follow Albert. We are him. His vision. His experience. The ground is blasted, there are bodies all around him. He tries to run but his feet sink into the mud. Bullets fly past him. Felled men are screaming at his feet in fear and agony. Albert staggers forward. David is now right by him. They run together. Albert looks round and suddenly, David is hit. He falls to the ground, screaming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm shot! No! Albert instinctively goes to help. Bullets shower all around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just leave me. Leave me! Albert grabs him and drags him onwards with him - David screaming at the pain - Albert grimly determined. Shells explode around them as they stumble on. Other men are running and falling. Albert sees cover in a huge shell-hole so dives into it for a moment's reprieve from the gun fire. He sits in still terror for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be all right here. You'll be safe. Someone'll come for ya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albert. Albert, listen...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right. It's all right. We're Devon boys, yeah? David looks at Albert as though seeing him for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... Albert races onward. Back at the trench, Andrew waits - terrified - and then, back out of the mist step two men - heading back towards him. Then a third. They suddenly catch sight of Andrew waiting there with his gun pointed towards them. They slow down - in the terror of the assault, they had forgotten that death was waiting for them if they turned back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Time seems to slow down - Andrew shifts his gun from pointing at one - to the other - we see their individual faces. They are all just boys really. And suddenly, instinct hits Andrew - he charges up the ladder, and forward, firing - past the three men, towards the enemy. He chooses his death instead of theirs. A sudden barrage of machine gun fire all around him. Cut back to Albert, who makes his way to the edge of the shell hole. Bullets whizz inches from his head. He looks over to see a German machine gun position to his right. Bullets whizz past forcing him to duck. Andrew charges past other soldiers, ignoring their warnings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get down! Albert continues forward to dive into another shell hole, nearer to the German line. He scrambles from shell hole to shell hole. Now he's very close to the machine gun position. Albert takes a grenade, fumbles with the pin as his hands tremble. He finally gets the pin out and he hurls the grenade at the machine gunner. We see the explosion and the machine gun stop. Albert sprints over the top again and makes it all the way into the German trench. Albert runs through the trench, which seems curiously empty. Albert swings round as he sees the startling face of a gas- masked German holding a rifle on him. Albert readies his bayonet but the man is dead, slumped backwards against the side of the trench still upright. Albert spins round, his bayonetted rifle in front of him, ready for action, but there is only the ghostly sight of dead German soldiers. Albert is alone, everyone else is dead. All the dead wear gas masks. More British soldiers drop into the trench, among them Andrew. He stumbles in the mud, drops his rifle, recovers it, and races through the trench. He glimpses Albert ahead of him, stalking through the mist. Andrew breaks into a smile and rushes forward, prompting Albert to whirl with his rifle raised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Albert pauses just in time. Then he collapses against the side of the trench, overwhelmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albie. Andrew grabs Albert and holds him up, embracing him. Albert can barely whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We made it. We made it. A moment later, the pair of them hurry through the trenches. Albert spots more comrades around a corner and calls ahead to Andrew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andrew, this way out! Suddenly ANOTHER SOLDIER leaps from a trench branch between them, shouting in panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gas! Gas! Gas! An instant later, a gas cloud blasts through the trench. Andrew and Albert look in horror. It spreads towards them, too powerful to avoid. Andrew is closest, turns to Albert with a helpless -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albie... - before he takes the full power of it. An instant later, the white, deadly cloud encompasses Albert, too...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK. Close on hooves and boots, slogging through muddy water, several inches deep. Friedrich is walking along, leading Topthorn and Joey. Topthorn is limping. Something is wrong - Topthorn seems to be failing - he coughs badly, breathes strangely. Friedrich stops to check on him. An officer notices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, there's no stopping here. Keep them moving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, there's something wrong. This one needs to rest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no rest for them. Move them along. Move them along! Instead, Friedrich leads the horses under the cover of a low bridge for a brief respite. A moment later, Topthorn collapses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, please, please. Stay on your feet. No, please. No no no... Friedrich tries to help Topthorn valiantly struggling to get up but finally sinks to the ground again. This time he lies semi-conscious. He is dying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please please... Stay on your feet. Joey deeply upset nuzzles his nose into Topthorn but the life drains out him. Friedrich is in panic at Topthorn's quick
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. Please please... Friedrich continues to stroke Topthorn's head. Joey pushes Topthorn as if to stop him falling into unconsciousness. For a moment we think Topthorn will come round but he slips away and all life leaves his body. Friedrich solemnly strokes the horse, knowing all is lost. Joey does not understand. He pulls at Topthorn's reins, as if trying to pull him upright. Topthorn's body is inert, his head falls to the earth. Joey will not give up, he pulls at him desperately not understanding that Topthorn has died. Suddenly, Friedrich looks around. Chaos - all the German soldiers stream back past their position, scrambling to get their guns and helmets. An officer charges down the bank next to the bridge, screaming orders at Friedrich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're coming! Leave it, private! Friedrich tries to pull Joey away to safety but Joey will not leave Topthorn's body. Friedrich pulls at Joey, but Joey is too lost in his grief to care about or even notice the danger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave it! Come with me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to hell! The officer nods to two other soldiers who pull Friedrich to safety. As he's dragged away, he screams at Joey:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Run. Run! Run! Run! But this is all background noise to Joey's profound refusal to accept Topthorn is dead. He paws at the ground next to Topthorn, a horse standing over his best friend in a field, and he will never leave him. And then suddenly - from around a blind turn in the streambed, a huge, remorseless tank turns, heading right for Joey. He bolts, galloping down the streambed, until he reaches a barbed wire barrier - a dead end. He attempts to run up the banks, but they're blocked, as well. He rears up, but the tank keeps advancing. The tank is about to crush Joey. He has left it too late. He is about to die. But then, counter-intuitively, he runs straight towards the tank and...leaps over it - a leap he learnt from Emilie. Then scrambles up and over it and leaps down behind. Joey keeps on running. He is wild, frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Joey is free - in countryside - but there is blood pouring from his leg, clearly torn by his encounter with the tank. He runs on - it is becoming night - suddenly there are explosions to the left of him - this fast, elegant creature simply runs through the gaps between explosions. But as he charges on - the sky lights up in the direction he is heading. He is suddenly in the thick of battle. A shell explodes next to him, and he leaps entirely over a trench. Another explosion sends him leaping, but not far enough - he finds himself crashing downwards, and into a trench - and he races through it - and finds himself charging towards a German company. Both sides are equally startled - Joey charging through a thin trench lined with German soldiers - the soldiers, finding a live horse careering through them. In desperation, Joey scrambles out of the trench - and once again, rushes away from the fighting...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . But now it is very dark indeed - he is stumbling as he runs - there is blood mixed with the mud on his legs. Now it is total night - fog - confusion - he jumps again. And now everywhere there are potholes - the land is massively uneven - shells are exploding all around. And suddenly sees in front of him barbed wire. He crashes through it - more - he bursts through again - now dragging barriers behind him - the barriers tangle, pulling him up short - he flips and lands amongst even more barbed wire. He pulls and turns to release himself but it is impossible. The more he pulls, the more firmly he is trapped. He rises up, wild, magnificent, a beast fighting for his life. He is completely trapped. He cannot move. He cannot see. He is in pain. He falls. It feels like an end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Stand to, stand to - A young soldier, a Geordie, is on look-out duty. He looks through a periscope. He alerts his colleague in his thick, northern, Newcastle accent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's something moving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It looks like a cow. He passes the periscope to the second soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell would a cow be doing out there? We see what he sees - nothing but morning mist on the surreal landscape - and something strange. It is Joey in the distance
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That definitely isn't a cow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (handing over periscope) Well, what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. We see an almost identical scene of several German soldiers looking out at Joey just as the British soldiers had done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It can't be a horse. Nothing alive could be out there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It isn't a horse. It isn't a horse. The first German looks through his periscope. We see what he sees - Joey in the mist:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes - it's a horse. The second German looks through the periscope, stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a horse. A third German (PETER) lowers his binoculars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it's a horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Now all the soldiers are gathering to look out at Joey. A CAPTAIN now has the periscope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, bugger me. It's a horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lads, we should call him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you call a horse? The Geordie starts clicking his tongue, followed by all of his comrades. They all try to attract Joey's attention with tongue clicks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. The Germans hear the clicks and respond with a chorus of whistles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Now both sides are whistling. Even the captain joins in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Joey tries to rise, but remains entangled. He whinnies in pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Peter lowers his binoculars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's caught on the wire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh sod it... Geordie climbs up the side of the trench, and waves a white handkerchief tied to the end of his bayonet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think you're doing? Get back, do you hear me? Corporal, that's an order! Get back! Geordie, not receiving fire, is emboldened to stand up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to him, sir. We can't leave him. He waves the handkerchief to clearly signal he is no threat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. The Germans look at the young soldier making his way over No Man's Land.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a trap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I don't think so. I think he's trying to help. The second German cocks his rifle and starts to take aim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scare him back into his hole. The second German takes a shot aimed over the Geordie's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. The Geordie crouches for cover, waving his handkerchief more frantically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a white flag, ent it? You see the white flag!? I'm just after tending to this here horse, is all! The Georgie marshals his courage and stands again, waving the handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back, you stupid git! There's no fire from the German trenches. Muttering to himself, the Geordie marches forward towards Joey:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, he leadeth me into green pastures, he lay me down beside the still waters... The Geordie walks very slowly across the mud - there are bodies - the ground squelches beneath his feet. He waves his handkerchief as he walks. He crosses a narrow bridge that spans a flooded bomb crater. Joey, lying on his side, wrapped head to toe in barbed wire, covered in mud, watches Geordie approach. When Geordie gets too close, Joey freaks out and begins thrashing about. Joey whinnies a high scream of pain, because wire is cutting into his hide in several places, and as he thrashes it cuts him deeper. Particularly worrisome is a strand that's wrapped around his head, crossing right over his eye, threatening to slash it. The Geordie calls out in a soothing voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poor beastie. Poor babbie. It's alright. It's alright. Don't buck and wriggle so, you're only shredding yourself. Joey calms a little, still moving his head up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll blind yourself. He reaches Joey and surveys the formidable tangle of wire in which Joey's bundled. The Geordie soothes and at the same time gingerly tests other strands, trying to figure out where to begin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bugger me worthless - I didn't think to bring gloves or something to cut
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stabs his hand on one of the barbs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: OW! DAMN! OW!! There's a noise behind him, and the Geordie turns around to see the Peter (the German from the trench) standing several feet away, holding some wire cutters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought perhaps you might need these. He holds out the wire cutters. The Geordie, still frightened, stares stupidly at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the barbed wire?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, yeah I... Ummm, thanks. Cheers. Cheers... He reaches out and takes the proffered cutters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. He returns to Joey, nervous about turning his back. He tries to figure out where to begin cutting. He lifts a long strand of wire that wraps around Joey's neck, stretches across his shoulder and torso and around one of his front legs. He puts the wire in the crux of the cutters and is preparing to snip when Peter steps closer to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That...That's a very long strand. When you cut it, it's going to release this - He points to a wire wrapped around the wire the Geordie's lifting. Then he points to two other wires, similarly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - and this, and this, and they'll coil back rather violently, which I'm afraid will only wound the poor fellow further.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The Geordie nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You speak good English.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I speak English well. (re: the cutters) May I? The Geordie hands them over and Peter surveys the wires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if we cut his head free first? So he won't try to stand up and blind himself? And then -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pity you didn't bring a second pair. Then I could cut the wire here - He points to one of the wires entangled with the strand he'd been prepared to cut. Peter stands and shouts in the direction of his trench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! All at once one, two, three, six pairs of cutters come soaring through the air and splash into the watery crater. Moments later - Peter and the Geordie kneel beside Joey, each with a pair of cutters. Joey is calming down again. The Geordie positions himself across Joey's body so that when he's cut the wire, it won't coil back and cut Joey. Peter positions himself to be able to cut the two wires in quick succession, holding the first wire to stop it from springing back. Joey's completely still now. Peter points between Joey's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His blind spot. The cutters won't frighten him. If you could cut here, holding this wire - He points to wires that intersect the wire that crosses Joey's eye. Then he points to the wire across Joey's eye.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: PETER WE NEED MORE WIRE CUTTERS

direction.raw_text: I could -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say no more, I'm right behind you. As they reposition themselves, the Geordie says to Joey:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you understand what's happening, do you not, O Best Beloved? That you must lay so very nice and still. There's a lad, you're a remarkable horse, you are, helping us help you. There's a lad. There's a remarkable lad. The Geordie looks into Joey's huge eye as he and Peter get to work on their cutting. Joey returns his gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So how's things in yonder trench?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delightful. We read, we knit sweaters, and we train our rats to perform circus tricks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if ever you need any more rats, we can always send ours over. `Cause we've more than we need, strictly speaking. Besides, they scare off all the pretty girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our girls aren't afraid of rats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Big strapping German girls, eh? Kind what gives robust massages? They laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every Thursday! And they bring rum cake on your birthday. Both men smile at this while Joey is completely still; they work quickly, in concert, cutting the horse's head free of the wire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Joey raises his head, gives it a shake, neighs and then stirs a little. The two soldiers smile at one another. Then they set about cutting the rest of the wire; it's much easier now. The Geordie cuts through the last wire binding Joey's legs. The two soldiers help as the horse staggers upright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that horse! Look at the muscles he's got, them long legs. They're made for running, horses. Runnin' away from danger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Running away is all they have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yet we taught `em opposite. Running into the fray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: War horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. War horse. And there he is. What a strange beast you've become. The Geordie grabs hold of Joey's halter, though Joey shows no sign of running. Joey is finally free. The two men look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I take him back with me, yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since I supplied the cutters, the horse is mine. This is fair, no?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a pig's eye. He's English, plain to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you mean because he's so filthy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because he's so smart. And you're none too clean yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We could box. And the winner gets the horse. The Geordie smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thanks, pet. Must be careful not to start a war. (patting his pockets:) Do you have a coin of any sort?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coin toss?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. He takes a coin from his pocket, hands it to the Geordie, who looks at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Fritz - you're on. He flips the coin back to Peter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is not Fritz - it is Peter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter - I'm Colin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You call it, Colin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heads. Peter spins it in the air and lets it fall into the mud. They look down. Peter shakes his head, resigned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the face of my Kaiser and he does not look pleased with me. The horse is yours. They collect their helmets as snow begins to blow around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gone quiet, hasn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (PAUSE) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But wait half an hour and we'll be shooting again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a terrible shot, Pete, don't believe I'll ever hit the target. He hands back the cutters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. He notices the Geordie has offered his hand, as well. A beat, then Peter shakes with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheerio, mate. (RE JOEY:) You'll take good care of him, yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our strange beast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you take care of your own strange self. Peter tosses Geordie his cutters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colin! A pair of German cutters - in memory of your handsome friend from Dusseldorf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. Peter nods, and walks back to his trench. As he goes, the Geordie calls after him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll use `em back in the garden in South Shields. You keep your head down, now, Pete me lad! As he walks away, Peter turns back briefly, calling:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remarkable! A remarkable horse! The Geordie leads Joey towards the British trenches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Joey is now in the trenches, splashing about in the ankle deep water. He seems enormous in this cramped labyrinth. He is led past the broken and wounded soldiers who look at him with amazement, dumbfounded. It is a surreal image. The horse where horses shouldn't be. As Joey makes his journey through the trenches soldiers excitedly gather to watch him come by, taking pleasure in the saving of this single life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. We arrive at a section we recognise as the place from where Albert set off only the night before. Sergeant Martin is there - as one man helps a wounded soldier into a medical area. It is David, hobbling and looking shell-shocked. Another wounded soldier approaches, but Martin waves him on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're full up. Move on. David is seated next to Albert, who now seems in worse condition. His eyes are bandaged and he's wheezing. Andrew is nowhere to be seen. As a MEDICAL OFFICER checks Albert:.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gas got him - we had to wait till morning. The medic moves to Sergeant Martin, looking stricken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This can't be all of us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is all. (bellowing to the men) All walking wounded, away to the dressing station! Away to the dressing station!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER. Joey is led into the hospital area beyond the trenches. The Geordie leads him through the snowy streets. Bandaged men strewn around, wounded soldiers waiting for attention. The waiting soldiers gather to view the strange spectacle of the horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . At one of the dressing areas, a NURSE tends to Albert's damaged eyes. Behind him, we see Joey pass in the street, but Albert doesn't know it. Joey limps, his foreleg clearly injured. The Geordie soldier stops outside a makeshift hospital. Joey looks frail and exhausted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: storms over from his patients.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need a vet, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are no vets. We've scarcely any horses left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's cut all over, but this leg here's got the worst of it. Geordie strokes Joey as the Doctor examines him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's probably tetanus. It's no good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, sir - The Doctor heads back into the hospital, dismissive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've all these men to take care of, corporal, you can see that, can't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, sir, this horse can pull through anything. The doctor absorbs his earnest appeal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SAME. Elsewhere, a line of soldiers waiting for medical assistance are curious about what is going on. Blinded by gas, eyes bandaged, one of them turns toward the commotion. It is Albert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a horse they found, wandering about in No Man's Land. (easing him back onto a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Down you go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of an horse?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bloody miraculous kind of an horse, be my guess. Nothing makes it out of No Man's Land. Albert lies there, but can't let go of the thought:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miraculous horse...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SAME. Joey stands - breathing very deeply. The Doctor touches his wounded leg. The men from all over the medical area gather around Joey concerned about their new hero's pain. The doctor looks at the Geordie and frowns shaking his head "no."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the doctor:) He was alive, y'see, sir, where nothing survives, so to me and me mates, to the men, sir, he's - Well, we have high hopes for him -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should shoot him now. The Geordie is broken hearted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but I can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'd be a mercy, lad, that leg's not going to mend. The Doctor sadly addresses a nearby Sergeant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeant. Put him out of his misery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The doctor nods his head towards Joey. The sergeant, SERGEANT FRY, takes his gun from his holster, checks that it's loaded. He turns to some nearby NURSES, urging them away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ladies, if you please. Total silence from the crowd who have gathered. They thought they were there to see something wonderful. And now they find that they've gathered for an execution - but can't take their eyes off it. The Sergeant waves them back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, back off. Back off. The Geordie is the last to step away from Joey. The sergeant draws breath - before he steps forward to take aim. Joey is totally still, sensing the atmosphere. The sergeant cocks his pistol. Suddenly there is a strange owl like whistle from fifty yards away. Joey looks around startled. The sergeant turns Joey's head back around, raises his pistol once more. Then, the whistle again. Even the doctor notices this time. Joey turns. Slowly, the crowd parts - another owl whistle - and we see Albert, his eyes bandaged - walking forward blindly - guided by the hands of the crowd. One soldier urges Albert gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on. Do it again. One more whistle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joey? And this time, Joey trots over to Albert. The horse nuzzles into him. Albert can't see Joey but he touches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Joey. Hello boy. Where you been then, hey? Where in the world you been? He strokes Joey's mane. Joey responds, becoming very still. The Doctor approaches with the Geordie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the Geordie:) Do you know this man? The Geordie shakes his head, no. The Doctor speaks to Albert, gently; clearly he thinks he's dealing with a traumatized, possibly crazy soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name? Albert, realizing he's being addressed, turns to the doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Narracott, Private Albert Narracott, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a random horse, Narracott, and too badly injured. (to the orderly) Is this man in your care?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not random at all, sir! He's my horse, I raised him, in Devon. Sir, look at his legs! He's got four white socks, he's brown all over - (points to his own
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - and he has a white mark here - like so... He makes the shape of a diamond with his hands. The doctor turns to the orderly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, son.
direction.name: direction
