direction.raw_text: Wait! You can't see `cause of the mud. The Geordie looks around, spots a bucket of water, grabs it and uses a rag to clean Joey's legs, revealing the socks. The Geordie looks at the doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four white socks! The doctor takes a rag himself and wipes Joey's snout, revealing the white diamond mark. The Sergeant takes this in...and holsters his pistol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, break it up. Clear off, the lot of ya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, sir? He's not random at all. The doctor steps up to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We will attend to your horse. Patch him up best we can. Treat him like the soldier he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, sir. With one last amazed look at Albert and Joey, the doctor returns to the hospital area. Moments later - Albert, the Geordie, and Sergeant Fry all lead Joey through the snowy street together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EARLY MORNING. Sergeant Fry strides into the middle of the throng of soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen! Gentlemen! It falls on me to give you some important news. At eleven o'clock today, in two minutes time - the War will come to an end. Shock from the troops. Strangely muted. Not the explosion of emotion you might have expected. Albert enters, his eyes still red, but no longer bandaged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King and Queen thank you for your service. We have been victorious - even if at a higher price than many of us might have imagined. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When the bells ring out - and they will in a moment, for the first time for four years - let us remember our brothers fallen in the field. And thank God for the end of this struggle and victory. And, in the distance, the church bells ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Joey stands tall, eating some hay, now healed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Complete change of atmosphere. Silence. Tension. Albert stands at attention with Sergeant Fry. A severe Major is behind his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Officers' horses only. All other horses are to be auctioned immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is a complete and bloody outrage. It's the lad's horse, sir, from Devon. He raised him up from a pup, he did. Trained him right up to the day when the army came to town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These aren't my orders, sergeant. (TO ALBERT) You'll have to take him to market. That's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STABLES, DAY. Albert puts on a brave face as he collects Joey and leads him out of the stables in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . As Albert comes out the men have gathered. There's a strange sense of optimism, for such a gloomy moment. The Geordie comes up to Albert and hands him a sheaf of pound notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've all clubbed together. It's everything we have. There's twenty-nine pounds there. Buy him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does the Major know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Major put in ten. The Geordie flashes a sly wink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mum's the word where the Major's concerned. Your friend on the crutches over there - He turns to indicate David Lyons, who nods at Albert solemnly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - even asked the Major to say that Joey was his, an officer's horse, so that he could go back with the others. Albert is amazed. He is about to show his gratitude when the sergeant major shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Narracott! Get a move on. We don't want to miss the show. Albert snaps to attention and begins to lead Joey out of the parade ground with the other horses. As they walk off, the sergeant silently adds some of his own money to the notes in Albert's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARKET PLACE. DAY. The intense bustle of the market. Farmers are gathered, bidding for horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven pounds! Seven pounds there! Seven pounds! Eight pounds here! A groom leads Joey to the auction pen with other horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eight pounds! Ten pounds here! Any advance? Sold!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. Albert waits anxiously, the Geordie lad by his side, as Joey is led into the pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're alright. Nobody's gonna bid more than fifteen for a thoroughbred. They want work horses. The auctioneer starts the bidding on Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next one. We start at four pounds. Four pounds. The farmers seem disinterested, shaking of heads. The bidding starts. Five pounds, six, seven, now it goes slowly, eight, nine, ten. Albert looks pleased at how it's going. He feels the cash in his hand. It seems to stick on ten, then a new hand comes up at the back of the auction - it is a nasty looking moustached man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleven. Sergeant Fry scowls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the butcher from Cambrai. He's been bidding for the best all morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleven. Eleven pounds. Eleven pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me handle this, private. (he calls out) ) Fifteen, and let that be an end to it. He looks daggers at the Butcher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifteen pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sixteen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sixteen pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seventeen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty of your English pounds. And let THAT be the end of it, my friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty Five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty five pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty Six.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty six pounds. The men are all looking very worried... There's not much left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty seven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty eight pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty nine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And thirty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any advance at thirty pounds? Then, from the back, another, new French voice...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One hundred pounds. He steps to the front of the crowd, and suddenly we see who it is. It is Emilie's Grandfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And sir, if you bid against me, I will sell the coat on my back and bid to one hundred and ten. And if you bid against me again, I will sell my farm and bid to a thousand. Everyone looks at Albert who is devastated. Albert is reeling. He hears the auctioneer repeat the final amount and brings down his gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One hundred pounds. Going, going, gone. The soldiers slowly disperse, leaving Albert to stare at Joey. It really is all over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE SAME. The Grandfather finishes paying for Joey. Albert and the Geordie stand in front of the grandfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I'll give you all your money. Everything you paid when we get back to England. I'll give you twice -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know anything about him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but you're wrong, sir, I know everything!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, you found him! I heard you found a horse in the wire between the armies -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I found him, he raised him - The Grandfather goes to Joey and takes his reins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I heard about the miracle horse, I traveled three days because I knew whose horse it was. My granddaughter's. She saved his life! He was everything to her. He pauses, briefly, to collect himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is your granddaughter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The war has taken everything from everyone. He is all that I have left of her. The Grandfather leads Joey away. Joey pulls, firmly but not wildly, on the rein the grandfather's holding. The grandfather lets go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He watches as Joey walks to Albert and nuzzles him. They have a moment together. The Grandfather watches carefully. Albert puts his face right near Joey - speaks gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be worried, boy, when I go. I won't worry over you none. Hey, I found you, didn't I, and you found me. Grandfather softens and begins to wonder about this soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we'll both... we'll both know that we made it through. Now go on. He leads Joey back to the Grandfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're the lucky ones. Always have been. Lucky since the day I met you. He quietly hands over the reins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God be with you, sir. The grandfather looks at Albert, then takes the regimental pennant from his pocket:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know what this is? Albert's amazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my father's. It's his regimental pennant. How did you come by this, sir? Grandfather hands Albert the pennant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may have this. Albert takes the pennant and looks at it, his eyes filling with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you ever so much for this, sir...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with a sigh) ... And this. He hands Albert Joey's reins. Albert turns to face him, almost mute with disbelief. He reaches for his money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No no, not necessary. He belongs to you. That is, of course, what my little girl would have wanted. And she was the boss. Grandfather laughs, then turns and slowly walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was her name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emilie. (turns back with a smile) Her name is Emilie. Albert gently embraces Joey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DEVON. DUSK. Suddenly, we are back in the village in Devon, in the fold of the valley. Dusk light. A figure approaches, silhouetted against the setting sun. Mrs. Naracott gathers the harvest, then notices as the figure makes its way up the road to the farm. A man in uniform. On a magnificent horse. Mrs. Narracott meets them at the gate and we can finally see them clearly - Albert and Joey. Albert dismounts and removes his cap. An instant later, Mrs. Narracott is hugging him for all that her life is worth.
direction.name: direction
